Description: THE NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL CONSERVE THE BEEKMAN FAMILY COACH, ONE OF ONLY THREE 18TH-CENTURY VEHICLES USED IN NORTH AMERICA TO SURVIVE WITH NEARLY ALL OF ITS ORIGINAL COMPONENTS AND THE ONLY EXTANT EXAMPLE FROM THE COLONIAL ERA. THE TREATMENT WILL REMOVE A DANGEROUS TOP LAYER OF VARNISH COVERING THE COACH BUT PRESERVE APPROPRIATE EVIDENCE OF WEAR IN ORDER TO MAXIMIZE THE EDUCATIONAL VALUE OF THE PIECE WHILE ALSO CORRECTING DANGEROUS AND VISUALLY DRAMATIC SURFACE LOSSES OR DISFIGUREMENT, CORROSION OR STRUCTURAL DAMAGE, AND SECURING THE OBJECT'S FUTURE STABILITY. BECAUSE MUCH OF THE CONSERVATION TREATMENT WILL TAKE PLACE IN A PUBLIC GALLERY, EVERY VISITOR TO THE MUSEUM AND LIBRARY WILL SEE THE ONGOING WORK, AS WILL THOSE PASSING BY THE MUSEUM'S STREET-FACING GLASS ENTRYWAY. AS PART OF A HISTORICALLY VALUABLE COLLECTION OF DOCUMENTS AND ARTIFACTS THAT PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE RECORD OF PRE-REVOLUTIONARY AMERICAN LIFE, THE BEEKMAN COACH BRINGS TO LIFE THE POLITICAL, ECONOMIC, AND SOCIAL HISTORY OF COLONIAL AMERICA.

THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI WILL CATALOG, INVENTORY, DIGITIZE, AND REHOUSE A COLLECTION OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL MATERIALS AND ASSOCIATED RECORDS FROM NEARLY 700 SITES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI. ACQUIRED VIA SURVEYS AND EXCAVATIONS CONDUCTED BETWEEN 1917 AND TODAY, THE COLLECTIONS COMPRISE CERAMICS, STONE, BONE, SHELL, CHARCOAL, METAL, AND GLASS SPANNING 14,000 YEARS OF HUMAN OCCUPATION IN THE SOUTHEAST. PARTICULARLY WELL REPRESENTED ARE ARCHAIC PERIOD ASSEMBLAGES, WOODLAND PERIOD MOUND AND VILLAGE SITES, MISSISSIPPIAN MOUND SITES AND VILLAGES, AND ASSEMBLAGES FROM THE BLACK PRAIRIE REGION ASSOCIATED WITH HISTORIC CHICKASAW AND THEIR LATE MISSISSIPPIAN TO EARLY CONTACT PERIOD ANCESTORS. THE PROJECT WILL ENSURE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THESE MATERIALS AND IMPROVE ACCESS TO THEM AS A RESOURCE FOR SCHOLARLY RESEARCH, STUDENT TRAINING, MUSEUM EXHIBITIONS, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMS.

CARNEGIE HALL WILL CONSERVE AND DIGITIZE 410 ARCHITECTURAL DRAWINGS DOCUMENTING THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE MUSIC HALL IN 1891 AND SUBSEQUENT RENOVATIONS AND IMPROVEMENTS MADE TO THE NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK BUILDING. THE DRAWINGS INCLUDE THE WORK OF ARCHITECTS WILLIAM B. TUTHILL, ELY JACQUES KAHN, ROBERT ALLAN JACOBS, AND JOHN J. MCNAMARA. TOGETHER WITH THE INSTITUTIONAL RECORDS HELD AT THE CARNEGIE HALL ARCHIVES, THE DRAWINGS DOCUMENT THE HISTORY AND DEVELOPMENT OF CARNEGIE HALL AS ONE OF THE PREMIER VENUES IN THE WORLD FOR CLASSICAL MUSIC. THE ARCHIVES ALSO SUPPORT THE STUDY OF THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION MOVEMENT IN NEW YORK CITY, WHICH SAVED CARNEGIE HALL FROM DEMOLITION IN 1960 THROUGH A CITIZEN-LED CAMPAIGN.

THE JOHN F. KENNEDY PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY AND MUSEUM WILL CONSERVE AND DIGITIZE 52 FAMILY SCRAPBOOKS AND PHOTOGRAPH ALBUMS FROM THE PRESIDENT'S MOTHER, ROSE FITZGERALD KENNEDY, WHICH DATE FROM 1878 TO 1963, AS WELL AS 12,000 ADDITIONAL PHOTOGRAPHS ASSOCIATED WITH THREE GENERATIONS OF THE KENNEDY FAMILY. THE SCRAPBOOKS AND ALBUMS CONSIST OF FORMAL STUDIO PORTRAITS, SNAPSHOTS, NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS, AND EPHEMERA CHOSEN BY ROSE KENNEDY AND OTHER FAMILY MEMBERS. THE PROJECT WILL ENSURE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THESE MATERIALS AND MAKE THEM ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH THE LIBRARY'S WEBSITE. EXPANDING THE LIBRARY'S DIGITAL ARCHIVES TO INCLUDE FAMILY MEMORABILIA WILL ENRICH THE PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIAL AVAILABLE FOR THE STUDY OF THE KENNEDY PRESIDENCY AND A TRANSFORMATIVE ERA IN AMERICAN HISTORY.

THE FLORIDA MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY WILL INVENTORY, STABILIZE, AND REHOUSE THE COLLECTION OF 20,500 ARTIFACTS AND ASSOCIATED RECORDS FROM ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATIONS OF THE SEVENTEENTH-CENTURY FRANCISCAN MISSION SITE OF SAN JUAN DEL PUERTO, LOCATED NEAR MODERN-DAY JACKSONVILLE, FLORIDA, AND WILL MAKE THE COLLECTIONS AVAILABLE FOR STUDY THROUGH AN ONLINE DATABASE, THE COMPARATIVE MISSION ARCHAEOLOGICAL PORTAL. THE COLLECTIONS HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO PROVIDE IMPORTANT INSIGHTS INTO THE INTRODUCTION OF CHRISTIANITY INTO NORTH AMERICA, THE ORGANIZATION OF MISSIONS, AND HOW THEY CHANGED THROUGH TIME WITH THE INTRODUCTION OF EPIDEMIC DISEASES, INCURSIONS FROM ENGLISH MILITIAS, AND SHIFTS IN THE ECONOMY OF LA FLORIDA. THE MISSION ALSO HAS HISTORIC IMPORTANCE AS THE HOME BASE OF FRIAR FRANCISCO PAREJA, ONE OF THE CENTRAL FIGURES IN THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE FRANCISCAN MISSION SYSTEM IN SOUTHEASTERN NORTH AMERICA.

THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING WILL CREATE 2D AND 3D DIGITAL IMAGES OF SITE RECORDS AND ARTIFACTS RECOVERED FROM HELL GAP, A DEEPLY STRATIFIED ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE THAT PROVIDES A NEARLY CONTINUOUS 4,500-YEAR RECORD (11,000-6,500 BC) OF PALEOINDIAN OCCUPATION AND IS REMARKABLE BECAUSE OF THE EVIDENCE OF HUMAN ADAPTATION TO CLIMATE CHANGE AT THE END OF THE LAST ICE AGE. RECORDS PERTAINING TO SITE MATERIALS EXCAVATED IN THE 1960S AND FROM THE 1990S TO THE PRESENT INCLUDE FIELD NOTES, MAPS, PROFILES, PHOTOGRAPHIC SLIDES, B&W NEGATIVES, CATALOG CARDS, AUDIO TAPES, FILMS, AND CODING SHEETS. THE ARTIFACT ASSEMBLAGE INCLUDES FAUNAL BONE, PRESERVED DOMESTIC BUILDINGS, FIREPLACES, AND CHIPPED STONE OBJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A PERMANENT DIGITAL ARCHIVE THAT WILL BE AVAILABLE THROUGH AN OPEN ACCESS INTERNET PORTAL, MAXIMIZING PUBIC AND RESEARCH ACCESS TO THE SITE.

THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA MUSEUM OF THE NORTH WILL STABILIZE AND REHOUSE A COLLECTION OF 7,000 CATALOGUED ITEMS, INCLUDING CHIPPED AND GROUND STONE ARTIFACTS; CARVED ANTLER, BONE, IVORY AND WOOD IMPLEMENTS; POTTERY; DENDROCHRONOLOGY SAMPLES; AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION EXCAVATED FROM 13 LATE PREHISTORIC (C. AD 1000-1800) ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES ALONG THE KOBUK RIVER IN NORTHWESTERN ALASKA. THE WELL-PRESERVED ORGANIC ARTIFACTS PROVIDE A UNIQUE TOOL FOR SEVERAL AREAS OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESEARCH INCLUDING FAUNAL ANALYSIS, SUBSISTENCE, TRADE AND EXCHANGE, LAND USE, PAST DISTRIBUTIONS OF PLANTS AND ANIMALS, DENDROCHRONOLOGY, AND RADIOCARBON DATING. EACH OBJECT WILL ALSO BE PHOTOGRAPHED, AND IMAGES WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE MUSEUM'S PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE DATABASE TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY FOR ARCHAEOLOGISTS, TRIBAL REPRESENTATIVES, EDUCATORS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE MUSEUM OF IDAHO WILL REHOUSE AND STABILIZE THE WASDEN COLLECTION, WHICH WAS EXCAVATED FROM THE WASDEN SITE (OWL CAVE) BETWEEN 1965 AND 1977 AND REPRESENTS AN ESTIMATED 15,000 YEARS OF NATIVE AMERICAN OCCUPATION ON THE SNAKE RIVER PLAIN. COMPRISING THE COLLECTION IS EVIDENCE OF LATE PLEISTOCENE-EARLY HOLOCENE HUMAN OCCUPATION AND ACTIVITY IN THE FORM OF STONE AND BONE TOOLS, POTTERY SHERDS, SHELL, AND TEXTILE FRAGMENTS; MORE THAN 10,000 BONES OF LARGE MAMMALS INCLUDING BISON, WOOLLY MAMMOTH, HORSE, DIRE WOLF, AND CAMEL; MICROFAUNAL REMAINS; SOIL SAMPLES; ORIGINAL FIELD NOTES; EXCAVATION RECORDS; SITE MAPS; AND EXCAVATION PHOTOGRAPHS. THE PROJECT WILL INVENTORY, CATALOG, AND REHOUSE THE ENTIRE COLLECTION AND WILL STABILIZE VULNERABLE MATERIALS THEREBY ENSURING THEIR LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND MAKING THE OBJECTS AND ASSOCIATED INFORMATION ACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCH AND EXHIBITION.

THE SAN FRANCISCO ART INSTITUTE (SFAI) WILL CONSERVE TWO OF A GROUP OF SIX NEW DEAL ERA FRESCOES ON THE WALLS OF SFAI'S HISTORIC 800 CHESTNUT STREET CAMPUS. SFAI (THEN CALLED THE CALIFORNIA SCHOOL OF FINE ARTS) PLAYED A CENTRAL ROLE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE FRESCO AS AN ART FORM IN THE UNITED STATES IN THE 1930'S. COVERED FOR MORE THAN 70 YEARS BY OVERPAINT, THE MURALS WERE DISCOVERED RECENTLY IN 2013. THIS PROJECT WILL CONSERVE ANOTHER TWO FRESCOES, MARBLE WORKERS AT FISHERMAN'S WHARF BY FREDERICK OLMSTED, JR., AND THE LOST FRESCO #6, ARTIST UNKNOWN. TREATMENT WILL INCLUDE REMOVING URETHANE AND OVERPAINTING AND RESTORING DAMAGED AREAS OF THE FRESCOES. THE REVEALED FRESCOES WILL ILLUMINAT THE STORIES, EXPERIENCES, AND ETHOS OF BAY AREA PUBLIC MURAL ARTISTS, INCLUDING THOSE LESS PROMINENT, IN THIS VERY IMPORTANT PERIOD IN OUR COLLECTIVE HISTORY.

THE ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM WILL CONSERVE THE MUSEUM'S BLACK MOUNTAIN COLLEGE (BMC) COLLECTION, WHICH CONTAINS HISTORICAL MATERIALS AND CREATIVE WORKS BY STUDENTS AND TEACHERS WHO ATTENDED BMC DURING ITS OPERATION FROM 1933-1957. THE MOST AT-RISK ITEMS IN THE COLLECTION INCLUDE RAY JOHNSON LETTERS; DRAWINGS, TEXT, PRINTS, PAINTINGS, AND SCULPTURE FROM THE LORNA HALPER ESTATE; ADMINISTRATIVE DOCUMENTS, BULLETINS, AND PUBLICATIONS AND PERFORMANCE PROGRAMS; PAINTINGS BY OTHER SIGNIFICANT BLACK MOUNTAIN COLLEGE ARTISTS INCLUDE RENE PINCHUK, KENNETH NOLAND, JORGE FRICK, AND RICHARD LLOYD ANDREWS; AND FURNITURE FROM ONE OF THE FOUNDING FAMILIES OF BMC MADE BY MARY "MOLLY" GREGORY, HEAD OF THE BMC WOODWORKING PROGRAM. THE PROJECT WILL CONSERVE AND STABILIZE THE COLLECTION FOR FUTURE EXHIBITS AND RESEARCH AND INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING AND ACCESSIBILITY THROUGH DIGITIZATION AND EXHIBITIONS.

THE BUCKS COUNTY RECORDER OF DEEDS WILL CONSERVE 61 MISCELLANEOUS (NON-DEED) RECORD BOOKS DATING AS EARLY AS 1785 THAT INCLUDE INFORMATION REGARDING CHATTEL, EMANCIPATION OF SLAVES, MARRIAGES, COURT ORDERS, DECREES, CHARTERS AND CONSTITUTIONS OF CHURCHES, AGREEMENTS, BONDS, MILITARY DISCHARGES, BILLS OF SALE, DOWER RELEASE, POWERS OF ATTORNEY, AND RELEASES OF EXECUTORS AND OF GUARDIANS. CONSERVATION TREATMENT TO STABILIZE, DEACIDIFY, AND REBIND THESE RECORDS WILL MAKE THEM AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCHERS, GENEALOGISTS, EDUCATORS, AND LOCAL ADMINISTRATORS. PLANS ARE ALSO BEING DEVELOPED FOR A "BOOK TOUR" TO OTHER LOCAL HISTORICAL SITES.

THE PRORODEO HALL OF FAME AND MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN COWBOY WILL PRESERVE A UNIQUE SET OF 120 PANORAMIC AND OVERSIZED RODEO PHOTOGRAPHS SPANNING THE YEARS 1919-1957. THE COLLECTION DOCUMENTS THE PEAK YEARS OF RODEO COMPETITION IN THE UNITED STATES, AND IT ILLUSTRATES THE EVOLVING IMAGE OF THE AMERICAN COWBOY, THE EXTRAORDINARY MID-20TH CENTURY POPULARITY OF RODEO CULTURE, AND THE WAYS IN WHICH THE IDEALS OF WESTERN AMERICAN CULTURE PERMEATED INTO AMERICA'S SELF-IMAGE. THE PROJECT WILL CLEAN, RESTORE, AND DIGITIZE THE ENTIRE COLLECTION, MAKING IT AVAILABLE FOR DISPLAY, RESEARCH, AND ACCESS BY THE PUBLIC.

THE BERKELEY ART MUSEUM AND PACIFIC FILM ARCHIVE (BAMPFA) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA WILL CONSERVE THE HAWK FOR PEACH (1968), A SIGNATURE LARGE-SCALE STABILE BY CELEBRATED AMERICA ARTIST ALEXANDER CALDER, AND WILL RE-INSTALL IT ON A NEW SITE ADJACENT TO BAMPFA'S NEW BUILDING IN BERKELEY. THE STABILE WAS COMMISSIONED BY BAMPFA IN 1968 AND DONATED BY CALDER IN MEMORY OF HIS BROTHER-IN-LAW KENNETH AURAED HAYES, A MEMBER OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY CLASS OF 1916. THE TREATMENT PROTOCOL, FOLLOWING THE STANDARDS OF THE CALDER FOUNDATION, WILL INVOLVE HAND STRIPPING TO BARE METAL, TREATMENT OF CORROSION, APPLICATION OF AN EPOXY PRIMER, AND APPLICATION OF A TOP COAT.

THE GETTY RESEARCH INSTITUTE WILL PRESERVE AND MAKE ACCESSIBLE ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS THAT INCLUDE CORRESPONDENCE, MANUSCRIPTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS DOCUMENTING THE WOMEN?S BUILDING, AN EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION FOUNDED IN 1973 IN LOS ANGELES. DEDICATED TO THE CREATION AND PRESENTATION OF FEMINIST ART, THE WOMEN?S BUILDING SUPPORTED THE WORK OF VISUAL ARTISTS JUDY CHICAGO AND NANCY BUCHANAN; PERFORMERS TERRY WOLVERTON AND LILY TOMLIN; AND WRITERS ADRIENNE RICH AND ALICE WALKER. THE PROJECT WILL CREATE FINDING AIDS FOR THE COLLECTIONS AND WILL DIGITIZE THE AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS, MAKING THEM AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCH.

THE NEW YORK STATE ARCHIVES WILL CONSERVE SEVERAL COLLECTIONS OF HISTORICAL DOCUMENTS CREATED BETWEEN 1775 AND 1783 THAT DOCUMENT BOTH THE PATRIOT GOVERNMENT?S PROSECUTIONS OF LOYALISTS AND THE BRITISH OCCUPATION AND GOVERNMENT OF NEW YORK CITY DURING THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION. CONSERVATION TREATMENT OF THESE FRAGILE DOCUMENTS WILL BE THE FIRST STEP IN MAKING THEM AVAILABLE TO SCHOLARS, STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE STATE ARCHIVES WILL DIGITIZE THE COLLECTIONS AFTER CONSERVATION TO INCREASE THEIR ACCESSIBILITY.

THE FRIENDS OF TIMBERLINE WILL CONSERVE SELECTED WORKS OF ORIGINAL ART CREATED FOR TIMBERLINE LODGE UNDER THE WORKS PROGRESS ADMINISTRATION (WPA) FROM 1936-1938. THE COLLECTION INCLUDES WORKS IN A VARIETY OF MEDIA, SUCH AS BAS RELIEF CARVINGS, MOSAICS, PAINTINGS, METAL WORK, LITHOGRAPHS, AND CARVED LINOLEUM. THE COLLECTION HAS DETERIORATED DUE TO EXPOSURE TO VARYING TEMPERATURES AND HUMIDITY, UV LIGHT INFILTRATION, AND INCREASED VISITATION. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE STABILIZATION AND CONSERVATION OF HAND-CARVED WOODEN NEWEL POSTS, LINOLEUM PANELS, WOODEN DECORATIVE PANELS, AND MARQUETRY PANELS.

THE ARIZONA STATE MUSEUM WILL PRESERVE ITS ANTHROPOLOGICAL PHOTOGRAPH COLLECTION, WHICH DOCUMENTS 13,000 YEARS OF HUMAN OCCUPATION, INGENUITY, AND ARTISTRY IN WHAT IS NOW THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST, FROM ANCIENT TIMES TO THE PRESENT. CONTAINING MORE THAN 525,000 PHOTOGRAPHIC PRINTS, NEGATIVES, AND TRANSPARENCIES, AND MORE THAN 250 MOVIE FILMS, THE COLLECTION ILLUSTRATES MILESTONES IN AMERICAN ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY. THIS PROJECT WILL CONSOLIDATE THE COLLECTION INTO A SINGLE, CLIMATE-CONTROLLED STORAGE FACILITY THAT WILL ALLOW IMPROVED ACCESS TO AND INHIBIT DETERIORATION OF THE COLLECTION.

THE MYSTIC SEAPORT MUSEUM WILL CONSERVE 3,500 CELLULOSE DIACETATE NEGATIVES IN THE ROSENFELD COLLECTION OF MARITIME PHOTOGRAPHY, ONE OF THE LARGEST PHOTOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS OF THE MARITIME INDUSTRY. DATING FROM 1927 TO THE 1950S, THE IMAGES DOCUMENT THE GOLDEN AGE OF AMERICAN YACHTING. THE MUSEUM WILL RECOVER NEGATIVES AFFECTED BY A FORM OF DETERIORATION KNOWN AS VINEGAR SYNDROME, WHICH WILL ALLOW THEM TO BE REHOUSED, DIGITIZED, AND MADE AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCH AND EXHIBITION.

VICTORIA MANSION?S PROJECT TO CONSERVE THE PAINTED DECORATION OF ONE OF ITS MOST ELABORATE AND ART-HISTORICALLY RICH SPACES, THE PARLOR, SEEKS TO STABILIZE AND PRESERVE THE ORIGINAL DECORATIVE PAINT SURFACES, REMOVE OVER 160 YEARS OF ACCUMULATED SOOT AND GRIME, AND IN-PAINT SMALL LOSSES AND ABRASIONS TO PRESERVE AND REVEAL THE ORIGINAL INTENT OF ARTIST GIUSEPPE GUIDICINI.  GUIDICINI?S WORK, THOUGH NOW LARGELY DESTROYED AND FORGOTTEN, WAS FAMED IN THE MID-19TH CENTURY, AND A FORTHCOMING MAJOR SCHOLARLY PUBLICATION DETAILING HIS INFLUENCE IN AMERICAN ART HISTORY WILL ONCE AGAIN PLACE HIM IN HIS PROPER HISTORICAL CONTEXT.  THE DECORATIONS IN VICTORIA MANSION COMPRISE THE ONLY EXTANT SURVIVAL OF HIS MURALS IN AMERICA, THUS MAKING IT A SINGULAR TOUCHSTONE FOR UNDERSTANDING THIS ARTIST?S WORK AND CONTRIBUTION TO AMERICAN CULTURAL GROWTH AT AN IMPORTANT JUNCTURE IN THE NATION?S HISTORY.
  THE THREAT OF LOSS TO IMPORTANT COMPONENTS OF THIS VISUALLY-RICH ROOM WAS UNDERLINED BY THE RELATIVELY RAPID DETERIORATION OF TWO ILIAD THEMED CEILING PAINTINGS, WHICH WERE REMOVED AND PLACED IN PROTECTIVE STORAGE IN 2014 TO AWAIT FURTHER TREATMENT.  CLOSELY MONITORED BY OUR STAFF CONSERVATOR SINCE THEN, THE WALLS AND CEILING HAVE REMAINED RELATIVELY STABLE BUT ARE CLEARLY COMPROMISED BY ACCUMULATED SURFACE DIRT AND WATER DAMAGE DUE TO LEAKS FROM A HISTORIC BATHROOM (NOW DISCONNECTED) ABOVE THE NORTH-EAST CORNER OF THE ROOM ALONG WITH SCATTERED AREAS OF POORLY MATCHED AND DISFIGURING IN-PAINT FROM PRE-1942 AMATEUR CAMPAIGNS TO "FRESHEN" THE ROOM?S APPEARANCE.
  THE PROPOSED TREATMENT FOLLOWS SUCCESSFUL PROTOCOLS DEVELOPED IN PREVIOUS CONSERVATION WORK IN THE MANSION AND INVOLVES CONCURRENT PUBLIC PROGRAMMING THAT PUBLICIZES AND EMPHASIZES NOT ONLY THE IMPORTANCE OF THE SURVIVING WORK, BUT ALSO THE ROLE CONSERVATION PLAYS IN PRESERVING THESE WORKS TODAY.  AT ITS FINISH, THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A STABLE AND FULLY-CLEANED ROOM THAT WILL REVEAL THE ART-HISTORICAL ROOTS, LUSH CONCEPT OF DECORATION, AND DAZZLING TONAL AND COLOR INTERACTIONS INTENDED BY ITS ORIGINAL CREATOR AND HIS PATRONS.

THE GLENN A. BLACK LABORATORY OF ARCHAEOLOGY OF INDIANA UNIVERSITY WILL REORGANIZE AND REHOUSE THE ARTIFACTS, FIELD NOTES, AND IMAGES ASSOCIATED WITH SYSTEMATIC ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATIONS (1939-1983) AT THE 100-ACRE ANGEL MOUNDS NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK SITE (AD 1250-1600). ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE REHOUSING OBJECTS, PAPER, AND MEDIA RECORDS IN MUSEUM-APPROPRIATE ACID-FREE CONTAINERS; IMPLEMENTING BEST PRACTICES IN MOLD MITIGATION; DIGITIZING RECORDS AND PHOTOGRAPHS; UPDATING ARTIFACT CATALOG RECORDS, CORRECTING ERRORS, REVISING INVENTORIES; AND MOVING RE-BOXED BULK COLLECTIONS TO A CLIMATE-CONTROLLED FACILITY. THE PROJECT WILL ENSURE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF THESE MATERIALS AND MAKE THEM ACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCH, EXHIBITION, AND EDUCATION.

SAM.GOV HISTORIC PRESERVATION FUND GRANTS-IN-AID ASSIST IN THE IDENTIFICATION, EVALUATION, AND PROTECTION OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES BY SUCH MEANS AS EDUCATION, SURVEY, PLANNING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, PRESERVATION, DOCUMENTATION, AND FINANCIAL INCENTIVES AVAILABLE FOR HISTORIC PROPERTIES.  OPPORTUNITY P23AS00652 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION FUND- ANNUAL TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE GRANTS SUPPORT ACTIVITIES AUTHORIZED BY THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT (NHPA) IMPLEMENTED BY THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICES ON TRIBAL LANDS UNDER THEIR PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. THIS GRANT IS AWARDED TO CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF WARM SPRINGS RESERVATION TO COMPLETE PROJECT WORK IN THE 8 PROGRAM AREAS AS DEFINED IN THE NHPA, AS APPLICABLE, AND RELATED ELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES.

15.904 HISTORIC PRESERVATION FUND GRANTS-IN-AID  AACR PRESERVATION  SAM.GOV HISTORIC PRESERVATION FUND GRANTS-IN-AID ASSIST IN THE IDENTIFICATION, EVALUATION, AND PROTECTION OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES BY SUCH MEANS AS EDUCATION, SURVEY, PLANNING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, PRESERVATION, DOCUMENTATION, AND FINANCIAL INCENTIVES LIKE GRANTS AND TAX CREDITS AVAILABLE FOR HISTORIC PROPERTIES.  OPPORTUNITY P22AS00648  AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS (AACR) IS A COMPETITIVE PHYSICAL PRESERVATION GRANT PROGRAM TO DOCUMENT, INTERPRET, AND PRESERVE THE SITES AND STORIES OF THE FULL HISTORY OF THE AFRICAN AMERICAN STRUGGLE TO GAIN EQUAL RIGHTS AS CITIZENS FROM THE TRANSATLANTIC SLAVE TRADE FORWARD. PROJECTS ARE FOR HISTORIC SITES LISTED IN, OR ELIGIBLE FOR LISTING IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER, AND INCLUDE ARCHITECTURAL SERVICES, HISTORIC STRUCTURE REPORTS, PRESERVATION PLANS, AND PHYSICAL PRESERVATION TO STRUCTURES. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATES, TRIBES, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND NONPROFITS. THIS PROJECT IS AWARDED FOR HAZARDOUS MATERIAL ABATEMENT, ADA ACCESS, AND REPAIRS TO THE FOUNDATION OF DEXTER AVENUE KING MEMORIAL BAPTIST CHURCH AND PARSONAGE IN MONTGOMERY, AL.

BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATES, TRIBES, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND NONPROFITS. THIS PROJECT IS AWARDED TO THE NON-PROFIT AMERICUS-SUMTER COUNTY MOVEMENT REMEMBERED COMMITTEE FOR INSTALLATION OF NEW ELECTRICAL AND HVAC SYSTEMS AND REPAIRS TO THE INTERIOR OF THE HISTORIC SITE OF THE AMERICUS COLORED HOSPITAL.

THIS GRANT FUNDS A BROAD RANGE OF HISTORY PROJECTS INCLUDING SURVEY AND PLANNING, RESEARCH AND DOCUMENTATION, INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION, AND COLLECTIONS CONSERVATION. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATES, TRIBES, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND NONPROFITS. THIS PROJECT IS AWARDED TO ELIZABETH CITY STATE UNIVERSITY FOR RESEARCH, DESIGN, AND CONSTRUCTION OF EXHIBITS TO INTERPRET THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMITMENT TO EDUCATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE GRANTS TO THPOS FOR THE IDENTIFICATION, EVALUATION, AND PROTECTION OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES BY SUCH MEANS AS  SURVEY, PLANNING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATION, EXPANSION OF THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES, AND TO ASSIST THPOS IN CARRYING OUT THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACTIVITIES THAT THE TRIBE AGREED TO ASSUME FROM THE STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE, ON TRIBAL LANDS, UNDER THEIR PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. AWARDS UNDER THIS PROGRAM MUST COMPLY WITH AND SUPPORT 54 USC 301 ET SEQ.  COMMONLY KNOWN AS THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT OF 1966, AS AMENDED .

THE PROJECT WILL REHABILITATE THE GEORGIA B  WILLIAMS NURSING HOME TO HOUSE MUSEUM EXHIBITS AND AN HISTORICAL INTERPRETATION OF ORIGINAL BIRTHING CENTER SPACES  THE GOAL OF THE MUSEUM IS TO SPOTLIGHT THE ROLE OF THE SOUTHERN AFRICAN AMERICAN MIDWIFE IN AMERICAN SOCIETY SINCE THE COUNTRY S INCEPTION, WITH A FOCUS ON THE ROLE MIDWIVES PLAYED IN PROVIDING AN ESSENTIAL SERVICE DURING THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT  THE FIRST PHASE OF REPAIRS INCLUDES STABILIZATION AND DOCUMENTATION  THE TEMPORARY SEALING OF THE EXTERIOR AS NEEDED, ROOF REPAIR AND CHIMNEY REPAIR, AND A FOUNDATION ASSESSMENT  THE MUSEUM WILL HELP TO TELL A FULLER STORY OF SEGREGATION, THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT IN THE RURAL AMERICAN SOUTH, THE STRUGGLE FOR HEALTHCARE EQUALITY, AND BLACK FEMALE INGENUITY AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP

THE SANDY ISLAND SCHOOL WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1932 AND PROVIDED A 9 MONTH QUALITY EDUCATION TO SANDY ISLAND CHILDREN UNTIL THE 8TH GRADE  IT ALSO HELD ADULT EDUCATION COURSES FOR VOTER REGISTRATION EDUCATION IN THE 1950S AND THE 1960S, INCREASING SANDY ISLAND VOTER PARTICIPATION TO 100   THIS GRANT WILL FUND REPLACEMENT OF THE DETERIORATING METAL ROOF, ADDITION OF INSULATION TO THE ATTIC, INCREASED ELECTRICAL INFRASTRUCTURE, AND THE ADDITION OF AN HVAC SYSTEM FOR CENTRALIZED HEATING AND COOLING  THESE REPAIRS WILL ALLOW THE BUILDING TO BE TRANSFORMED FROM INTO A MULTI USE INTERPRETIVE AND LEARNING CENTER FOR THE SANDY ISLAND COMMUNITY AND CULTURAL TOURISTS ALIKE

OLD FORT NIAGARA WAS CENTRAL TO THE STRUGGLE FOR CONTROL OF THE GREAT LAKES BASIN FROM THE TIME THE FRENCH CASTLE WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1726 THROUGH THE WAR OF 1812  THE FORT IS CONSIDERED NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT BECAUSE IT PRESERVES ONE OF THE BEST COLLECTIONS OF 18TH CENTURY MILITARY ARCHITECTURE IN NORTH AMERICA AND ONE OF THE MOST EXTENSIVE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS LINKED TO AN 18TH CENTURY FORT  THE SITE ALSO SERVES AS A VENUE TO INTERPRET CROSS CULTURAL INTERACTIONS BETWEEN INDIGENOUS PEOPLES AND EUROPEAN COLONISTS  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE REHABILITATION OF MASONRY ON VARIOUS BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES AT THE SITE  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  1,350,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

MORVEN WAS BUILT C  1757 BY RICHARD AND ANNIS STOCKTON  RICHARD WAS ONE OF NEW JERSEY S DELEGATES TO THE SECOND CONTINENTAL CONGRESS AND A SIGNER OF THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE  ANNIS WAS ONE OF THE FIRST PUBLISHED FEMALE POETS IN AMERICA  THEIR SON, RICHARD, INHERITED THE HOUSE IN 1788 AND WAS ALTER ELECTED TO THE U S  HOUSE AND SENATE  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE REPAIR OF THE MANSION S WHITEWASH EXTERIOR, REPLACE THE ELEVATOR, AND UPGRADE EXTERIOR LIGHTING ON THE PROPERTY  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  186,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE BOOKER T  WASHINGTON HIGH SCHOOL WAS FOUNDED IN 1916 AS THE SECOND SEGREGATED SCHOOL FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN STUDENTS IN COLUMBIA, SOUTH CAROLINA  INITIALLY SERVING AS AN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, IN 1918 IT BECAME THE FIRST PUBLIC HIGH SCHOOL FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN STUDENTS IN COLUMBIA  THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE HOLISTIC REVITALIZATION AND PRESERVATION OF THE BUILDING  THE PROPOSED WORK COMBINES THREAT RESPONSE, EDUCATION AND PROMOTION OF CIVIL RIGHTS, CERTAIN FUNCTIONAL ENHANCEMENTS, AND INCREASED ACCOMMODATION OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT

FOLLOWING THE CIVIL WAR, NEWLY EMANCIPATED BLACK MARYLANDERS FOUND THEMSELVES NEGOTIATING A NEW WORLD, ONE FILLED WITH BOTH OPPORTUNITIES AND CONSTRAINTS  THE JEFFERSON PATTERSON PARK AND MUSEUM S  JPPM   WITNESSES OF WALLVILLE   PROJECT WILL, WITH THE HELP OF DESCENDANTS, ARTICULATE THAT HISTORY THROUGH A FOCUS ON WALLVILLE, A SMALL BLACK RURAL COMMUNITY IN CALVERT COUNTY, EXPLORING HOW THE COMMUNITY S RESIDENTS CRAFTED NEW LIVES AND NEW POSSIBILITIES EVEN AS THEY CONFRONTED RACISM AND BIGOTRY WELL INTO THE MID TWENTIETH CENTURY  THIS PROJECT WILL EXAMINE THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC HISTORY OF WALLVILLE S BLACK CITIZENS, AS WELL AS THE IMPORTANT ROLES OF CHURCHES, SCHOOLS, FRATERNAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND EXTENDED FAMILY FOR RESIDENTS OF WALLVILLE  THE PROJECT WILL CREATE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE INTERPRETIVE CONTENT, A TECHNICAL REPORT OF THE DOCUMENTARY, ORAL HISTORY, AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL FINDINGS  THE APPLICANT IS PROVIDING  35,485 IN ADDITIONAL FUNDS

THE RIVERSIDE HOTEL AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE TO AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS, SPANS ACROSS THREE ERAS  THE HOTEL STRUCTURE AS IT EXISTS TODAY, WAS BUILT AROUND 1925 UNDER SEGREGATION AND JIM CROW LAWS AS A BLACK HOSPITAL AND WAS BOUGHT IN 1944 BY MRS  ZL  HILL  THE HOTEL FOSTERED A VIBRANT BLACK MUSIC SCENE DURING THIS ERA, AND IT FUELED THE BEGINNING OF AN AMAZING LEGACY OF FAMOUS BLACK ARTISTS THAT EITHER STAYED OR BOARDED AT THE RIVERSIDE HOTEL  THE MAJOR GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO STRUCTURALLY STABILIZE THE HOTEL AND THE THREE ASSOCIATED SHOTGUN HOUSES, AND COMPLETE NEEDED EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR REPAIRS

THIS GRANT WILL PRESERVE THE FORMER RESIDENCE OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND POLITICAL LEADER GRACE TOWNS HAMILTON  B 1907   D 1992   HER ACTIVISM SUPPORTED VOTING RIGHTS, EQUAL EDUCATION, HEALTH CARE, HOUSING, AND IMPROVING WORKING CONDITIONS FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRESERVE THE HISTORIC INTEGRITY OF THE RESIDENCE AND ACTIVATE THE SPACE AS A COMMUNITY RESOURCE  THIS GRANT WILL FUND A FULL BUILDING ASSESSMENT AND REMOVE VEGETATION, MITIGATE WATER AND FIRE DAMAGE, AND REPLACE FLOOR FRAMING

THE LIZARD MOUND SITE IS A MOUND COMPLEX FEATURING 28 MOUNDS SURVIVE ON THE 20 ACRE SITE, WITH AN ADDITIONAL 3 ON ADJACENT PRIVATE PROPERTY  THE EXTANT MOUNDS INCLUDE 12 PANTHER EFFIGIES, 9 LINEAR, 6 CONICAL, 2 TAPERING LINEAR, AND 2 BIRD GOOSE EFFIGIES  MOUND CONSTRUCTION AND MORTUARY RITUALS OCCURRED ON SITE BETWEEN 750   1200 AD BY LOCAL INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES WHO ARCHAEOLOGISTS CALL LATE WOODLAND PEOPLE  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT LANDSCAPE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, TRAIL RELOCATION, AND SITE SECURITY  THE GRANTEE WILL PROVIDE  8,240 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE REHABILITATION OF THE RESIDENCE OF GEORGE ALEXANDER TOWNS  HE WAS A TRAILBLAZER IN THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT WHO REMAINED COMMITTED TO CIVIL RIGHTS FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS BETWEEN THE YEARS 1905 TO 1960  THE TOWNS RESIDENCE WAS BUILT IN 1910 IN THE ATLANTA UNIVERSITY CENTER  AUC  HISTORIC DISTRICT  THE PROJECT INCLUDES AN ADAPTIVE REUSE OF THE SPACE, WHICH WILL CONVERT THE HOME TO COMMUNITY EDUCATION SPACE  WORK COMPLETED AT THE SITE WILL INCLUDE REPAIRS DUE TO WATER INFILTRATION ISSUES AND FIRE AND SMOKE DAMAGE  THE HOME INTENDS TO SERVE AS A CULTURAL INSTITUTION THAT SUPPORTS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING RELATED TO CIVIL RIGHTS

GEORGE WASHINGTON MADE WALLACE HOUSE HIS WINTER HEADQUARTERS FROM 1778 79 AND WAS IN RESIDENCE THERE VARIOUS TIMES BETWEEN DECEMBER 1778 AND JUNE 1779  HE WAS JOINED THERE BY MARTHA WASHINGTON, ALEXANDER HAMILTON, JOHN LAURENS  AND SEVERAL ENSLAVED AND FREE SERVANTS  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT REPLACEMENT OF THE ROOF AS WELL AS OTHER EXTERIOR ENVELOPE REPAIRS FOR THE BUILDING

THE PAUL BRUHN HISTORIC REVITALIZATION SUBGRANT PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE SUBGRANTS FOR PRESERVATION ACTIVITIES ON PROPERTIES LISTED IN OR ELIGIBLE FOR THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES IN RURAL COMMUNITIIES  LESS THAN 50,000 POPULATION  IN VERMONT THAT ARE SELECTED THROUGH A COMPETITIVE PROCESS  ALL ASSOCIATED WORK MUST ADHERE TO THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR S STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES FOR ARCHEOLOGY AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION

THE INDIAN KING TAVERN WAS BUILT IN 1750 ALONG THE ROADS THAT CONNECTED PHILADELPHIA AND NEW YORK AND THE DELAWARE RIVER AND ATLANTIC OCEAN  THE NEW JERSEY LEGISLATURE MET IN THE BUILDING IN 1777, JUST MONTHS AFTER ADOPTING THE STATE S FIRST CONSTITUTION, SOLIDIFYING THE TAVERN S PLACE IN THE STATE S POLITICAL HISTORY  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT REPAIRS TO THE BUILDING S EXTERIOR ENVELOPE AND INTERIOR FINISHES  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  119,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE GOVERNOR STEPHEN HOPKINS HOUSE IS A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK, BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN BUILT ABOUT 1707  STEPHEN HOPKINS ACQUIRED THE HOME AND IN 1742 1743 ENLARGED THE STRUCTURE INTO THE EXTANT L SHAPED TWO STORY GEORGIAN FRAME HOUSE  HOPKINS WAS A PIVOTAL FIGURE IN EARLY RHODE ISLAND HISTORY AS A SURVEYOR, MERCHANT, CHIEF JUSTICE OF THE COLONIAL SUPERIOR COURT, TEN TIME ELECTED GOVERNOR OF RHODE ISLAND, DELEGATE TO ALBANY CONFERENCES  1754 AND  1755 , MEMBER OF THE FIRST AND SECOND CONTINENTAL CONGRESSES, AND A SIGNER OF THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE REHABILITATION AND REPAIR OF THE EXTERIOR ENVELOPE OF THE BUILDING

CLERMONT FARM WAS SURVEYED BY A YOUNG GEORGE WASHINGTON IN 1750 AND IS AN EXCELLENT ILLUSTRATION OF A FARM OF MIDDLING SIZE THAT WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE BACK COUNTRY ON THE COLONIAL FRONTIER  THE FARM S EARLY OWNERS WERE MIDDLING GENTRY, A CLASS OF PEOPLE WHO BECAME THE BACKBONE OF RESISTANCE TO BRITISH RULE, WHO FOUGHT AND SUPPLIED THE REVOLUTION, AND HELPED DEVELOPED THE NEW NATION  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE REHABILITATION OF THE MAIN HOUSE, SMOKE HOUSE, AND SPRING HOUSE  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  10,374 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE HENRY WHITFIELD HOUSE  1639  IS RECOGNIZED AS THE OLDEST HOUSE IN CONNECTICUT AND THE OLDEST STONE HOUSE IN NEW ENGLAND  AS ONE OF THE FEW SURVIVING HOUSES FROM THIS PERIOD, THE WHITFIELD HOUSE IS A TOUCHSTONE FOR VISITORS TO EXPERIENCE THE EUROPEAN SETTLER COLONIALISM OF THE 1600S IN ALL ITS COMPLEXITY AND THE BROAD CONTEXT OF THESE COLONIZING COMMUNITIES  DURING THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR, THE WHITFIELD HOUSE WAS HOME TO ONE OWNER WHO LEFT FOR HIS BRITISH SYMPATHIES, THEN ANOTHER WHO HARBORED FEARFUL PATRIOTS, REPRESENTING THE COMPLEXITY OF THE CITIZENS WHO CONDEMNED AND SUPPORTED THE REVOLUTION  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT REHABILITATION OF THE BUILDING ENVELOPE AND UPDATING OF THE ELECTRICAL SYSTEM  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  125,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

BRUNSWICK TOWN WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1725 AS THE ROYAL SEAT OF GOVERNMENT FOR THE COLONY OF NORTH CAROLINA  THE TOWN WAS THE FOCUS OF PATRIOT REVOLT AGAINST THE STAMP ACT AND BRITISH RULE AND BECAME AN EARLY BRITISH MILITARY TARGET  MOST OF THE TOWN WAS BURNED IN 1781 AND SURVIVES TODAY AS A RUIN WITH EVIDENCE OF THE CIVIL WAR  ERA FORT ANDERSON  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION OF THE RUINS OF THE ST  PHILIP S CHURCH AND NUMEROUS MARKERS IN THE ASSOCIATED GRAVEYARD ALONG WITH OTHER SITE IMPROVEMENTS  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  82,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE COLBURN HOUSE WAS BUILT BY MAJOR REUBEN COLBURN IN 1765 AND IS CLOSELY ASSOCIATED WITH BENEDICT ARNOLD S CAMPAIGN TO TAKE QUEBEC FORM THE BRITISH EARLY IN THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR  COLBURN WORKED WITH THE WABANAKI TRIBE AND LOCAL COLONISTS TO MAP A WATER TRAIL CONNECTING THE KENNEBEC RIVER TO QUEBEC AND OVERSAW THE CONSTRUCTION OF A FLEET OF BOATS AND GATHERING OF PROVISIONS FOR THE JOURNEY  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT REPAIRS TO THE BUILDING ENVELOPE, REMEDIATE MOLD, REPAIR INTERIOR SPACES, AND INSTALL A FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  80,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT EMERGENCY AND ESSENTIAL PRESERVATION WORK AT THE 1911 ENGLISH AVENUE SCHOOL IN ATLANTA S WESTSIDE  THIS LARGE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL HAS WITNESSED MANY MOMENTS AND MOVEMENTS IN HISTORY INCLUDING WOMEN S SUFFRAGE, CHILD LABOR LAWS, AND THE PURSUIT OF RACIAL JUSTICE  THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDS FOR A COMPREHENSIVE HISTORIC STRUCTURES REPORT, AND PHYSICAL PRESERVATION WORK INCLUDING EMERGENCY STABILIZATION AND WEATHERIZATION RELATED TO THE ROOF, GUTTERS, AND SCUPPERS  EMERGENCY BRICK WALL STABILIZATION  BIOLOGICAL MATERIAL ABATEMENT ON THE MASONRY  AND TO REPAIR DECORATIVE BROWNSTONE TERRACOTTA  THE APPLICANT IS PROVIDING  57,419 IN ADDITIONAL FUNDS

THE JAMES BRICE HOUSE  1774  WAS THE HOME OF JAMES BRICE WHO SERVED ON THE MARYLAND EXECUTIVE COUNCIL DURING THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR, SERVED AS MAYOR OF ANNAPOLIS WHILE THE CITY BRIEFLY SERVED AS THE U S  CAPITOL IN 1782 83 AND WAS APPOINTED ACTING GOVERNOR OF MARYLAND IN 1792  THE BRICK HOUSE IS A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK AND IS WIDELY STUDIED FOR ITS ICONIC HIGH GEORGIAN FIVE PART PLAN  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE RESTORATION OF THE BUILDING S 74 WOOD WINDOWS  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  20,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE MUSEUM OF THE IRONWORKER IS LOCATED IN ONE OF THE FEW SURVIVING PRE 1800 WORKER HOUSES AT CATOCTIN FURNACE AND INTERPRETS THE PEOPLE, METHODS, AND TOOLS INVOLVED IN IRONMAKING IN EARLY AMERICA  THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE REPLACEMENT OF THE HVAC SYSTEM TO PROVIDE BETTER CLIMATE CONTROL FOR THE BUILDING AND ITS ARTIFACTS  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  14,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

CATOCTIN FURNACE IS AN EARLY INDUSTRIAL COMPLEX BUILT BY THOMAS JOHNSON, MARYLAND S FIRST POST COLONIAL GOVERNOR, AND HIS BROTHERS IN THE 1770S  THE JOHNSONS CONSTRUCTED AND OPERATED THE FURNACE WITH LABOR FROM MORE THAN 200 ENSLAVED INDIVIDUALS, AND THE SITE ACTIVELY INTERPRETS THE PARADOX OF THE COLONISTS  QUEST FOR FREEDOM AND THEIR EMBRACE OF SLAVERY, ALONG WITH THE ROLE ENSLAVED PERSONS PLAYED IN THE INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT OF EARLY AMERICA  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE STABILIZATION OF THE RUINS OF THE C 1781 IRONMASTER S MANSION AND MAKE IT ACCESSIBLE FOR THE PUBLIC  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  14,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE OLD MULKEY MEETINGHOUSE STATE HISTORIC SITE IS HOME TO A FRONTIER CHURCH FOUNDED BY EARLY COLONISTS IN THE CUMBERLAND GAP, INCLUDING DANIEL AND SQUIRE BOONE  THE EARLY BAPTIST MEETINGHOUSE WAS A FOCAL POINT OF A GROWING EUROPEAN POPULATION IN THE AREA AND REPRESENTATIVE OF LOG BUILDING PRACTICES IN EARLY AMERICA  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT REPAIRS TO THE ROOF, LIGHTING UPGRADES, AND UPDATES TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER LISTING TO EXPAND RESOURCE BOUNDARIES AND INCLUDE ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES FROM EARLIER PERIODS  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  18,260 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE CORE OF MELROSE COTTAGE WAS BUILT C 1785 BY QUAKER FARMER JACOB VERNON AND HIS WIFE SARAH CHEYNEY ON A PARCEL OF LAND SHE RECEIVED INHERITED FOLLOWING THE DEATH OF HER FIRST HUSBAND THOMAS CHEYNEY  OVER THE YEARS THE HOUSE WAS EXPANDED AND THE ORIGINAL CHEYNEY FARM BECAME THE CAMPUS OF CHEYNEY UNIVERSITY, THE NATION S FIRST HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGE AND UNIVERSITY  THIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE REHABILITATION OF MELROSE COTTAGE INTO A VISITOR CENTER FOR THE UNIVERSITY

TIMBERNECK HOUSE IS LOCATED ON A PARCEL OF LAND THAT ENDURED AS A PROSPEROUS FAMILY FARM THROUGH FIVE GENERATIONS OF THE CATLETT FAMILY, FROM 1793 TO 2007  BEFORE THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION THE PROPERTY WAS PART OF A LARGE TOBACCO PLANTATION OWNED BY THE MANN AND PAGE FAMILIES AND WORKED BY DOZENS OF ENSLAVED AFRICAN WOMEN AND MEN  THE ORIGINS OF VIRGINIA S SLAVE BASED PLANTATION SYSTEM WERE CREATED AT LANDSCAPES LIKE TIMBERNECK, WHICH CONTAINS ARCHAEOLOGICAL TRACES OF 17TH   AND 18TH  CENTURY SETTLEMENTS  THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE REHABILITATION OF EXTERIOR ENVELOPE AND INTERIOR SPACES OF THE HOUSE  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE AN ESTIMATED  300,000 IN NON FEDERAL MATCH

THE ALSTON HOUSE PROJECT IS A PHYSICAL PRESERVATION PROJECT FOCUSED ON REVITALIZING THE HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT ALSTON HOUSE PROPERTY LOCATED ON GERVAIS STREET IN DOWNTOWN COLUMBIA, SC  IN 1872, MS  CAROLINE THOMPSON ALSTON BECAME OWNER AND OCCUPANT OF THE PROPERTY  MS  ALSTON, AN AFRICAN AMERICAN, OPERATED HER DRY GOODS STORE AT THIS LOCATION IN THE CITY BETWEEN THE YEARS OF 1875 AND 1895 AND WAS AT THAT TIME ONE OF ONLY 25 BLACK BUSINESS OWNERS IN THE STATE S CAPITAL CITY  THE PROJECT HAS TWO MAIN GOALS  COMPLETE INTERIOR AND EXTERIOR REPAIRS OF THE ALSTON HOUSE PROPERTY AND PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN WOMEN ENTREPRENEURS IN HONOR OF MS  ALSTON S CONTRIBUTIONS TO AFRICAN AMERICAN ENTREPRENEURSHIP

THE QUINN CHAPEL AFRICAN METHODIST EPISCOPAL  AME  CHURCH AKA CHESTNUT STREET BAPTIST CHURCH IS LOCATED ON THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE RUSSELL NEIGHBORHOOD, A PREDOMINATELY AFRICAN AMERICAN NEIGHBORHOOD  WITH A MISSION AGAINST RACIAL DISCRIMINATION WELL INTO THE 20TH CENTURY, THE CONGREGATION FOUGHT HOUSING SEGREGATION IN 1914, DESEGREGATION OF PUBLIC AMENITIES IN 1961, AND PROMOTED AN OPEN HOUSING ORDINANCE IN 1967  THE CHURCH PLAYED A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THESE MOVEMENTS BY RAISING MONEY, PROVIDING MEETING SPACE, AND HOLDING SPEAKING ENGAGEMENTS BY LEADERS SUCH AS REV  DR  MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR  AND CASSIUS CLAY  MUHAMMAD ALI   WITH THIS THIRD GRANT, A STABLE, WATERTIGHT BUILDING ENVELOPE WILL HELP EXECUTE FURTHER REHABILITATION AND ADAPTIVELY REUSE THIS HISTORIC RESOURCE AS A COMMUNITY ASSET  THE FUTURE GOAL FOR THE BUILDING IS A PERFORMING ARTS SPACE OR OTHER COMMUNITY FOCUSED SPACE

THE AMERICUS COLORED HOSPITAL OPENED IN 1923 IN AMERICUS, GEORGIA TO PROVIDE QUALITY MEDICAL CARE TO THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY  IT OPERATED UNTIL 1953 AND DURING THAT TIME PROVIDED FULL MEDICAL CARE AND TRAINED MORE MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS OF COLOR THAN ALMOST ANY OTHER HOSPITAL IN THE UNITED STATES  ONCE THE BUILDING IS REHABILITATED IT WILL HOUSE A CLINIC OPERATED BY SUMTER COUNTY HOSPITAL  AN HISTORICAL EXHIBIT OF HEALTHCARE AT THE FACILITY  MULTI PURPOSE AND MEETING ROOMS FOR CLASSES  HOST ORAL HISTORY RECORDINGS  AND A GALLERY TO EXHIBIT HISTORIC ELEMENTS AND PROMOTE THE WORK OF LOCAL ARTISTS ADDRESSING CIVIL RIGHTS  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANUP, FOUNDATION STABILIZATION, ROOF REPAIRS, NEW ELECTRICAL, HVAC, AND PLUMBING, AND NEW ADA COMPLIANT RESTROOMS

THE TUBAC PRESIDIO STATE HISTORIC PARK COMMEMORATES THE FIRST SPANISH SETTLEMENT IN ARIZONA IN 1752  THE MUSEUM, LOCATED IN SEVERAL ADOBE BUILDINGS THROUGHOUT THE COMPLEX, OFFERS EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMS RELATED TO THE INTERACTION OF CULTURES IN THE AREA AND THEIR INFLUENCE ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST  THIS GRANT WILL HELP REHABILITATE THE ADOBE MUSEUM BUILDINGS, INCLUDING STUCCO REPAIR, AND UPGRADES TO THE ELECTRICAL AND MECHANICAL SYSTEMS

THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE REHABILITATION OF THE VACANT HISTORIC MARY POTTER SCHOOL SHOP BUILDING TO SERVE THE PUBLIC AS A MULTI PURPOSE COMMUNITY AND LITERACY CENTER  FUNDS AWARDED WILL BE APPLIED TOWARD WORK IN THE EXISTING INTERIOR SPACE  HVAC, PLUMBING, ELECTRICAL, AND ELEVATOR INSTALLATION   THE BUILDING WILL ALSO SERVE AS A TOURIST ATTRACTION HIGHLIGHTING THE STRUGGLE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS AND HIGHLIGHT AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITIES IN GRANVILLE COUNTY AND THE MARY POTTER SCHOOL STORY  THE FORMER MARY POTTER ACADEMY HIGH SCHOOL VOCATIONAL BUILDING TAUGHT STUDENTS HOME ECONOMICS, TYPING AND SHORTHAND, CARPENTRY, WELDING, MASONRY, FARMING, AND OTHER VOCATIONAL SKILLS

THE COLLINS CHAPEL WILL USE THIS GRANT TO CONDUCT PHYSICAL PRESERVATION ACTIVITIES FOR THE CHURCH BUILDING AND HISTORICAL SITE TO ESTABLISH LONG TERM INTEGRITY OF THE PROPERTY  THE PRIORITY IS TO IMPROVE THE INFRASTRUCTURE IN ORDER TO MEET CURRENT SAFETY STANDARDS  SECONDLY, PLANS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO HIGHLIGHT THE HISTORIC BUILDING AND THE ORIGINAL ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN  ESTABLISHED IN 1841 AT A TIME WHEN AFRICAN AMERICANS COULD NOT LEGALLY OWN PROPERTY, COLLINS CHAPEL CHURCH IS ONE OF THE OLDEST, SURVIVING BLACK OWNED INSTITUTIONS IN THE SOUTH  THE APPLICANT IS PROVIDING  73,982 IN ADDITIONAL FUNDING

THE SULLIVAN BUILDING IN SELMA HOSTED FOUNDATIONAL VOTING RIGHTS ACTIVITIES FROM THE 1920S UNTIL 1965  THIS GRANT WILL LARGELY BE FOCUSED ON REGAINING STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OF THE BUILDING INCLUDING ROOF REPAIR  AND ELECTRICAL, PLUMBING REPAIR, AND DUCTWORK AS NEEDED  THE SPACE WILL BE USED TO PROMOTE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT BY PROVIDING A COMMUNITY CENTER AND CULTURAL SPACE TO INCLUDE A SMALL FOOD COURT AREA WITH KITCHEN INCUBATORS, FOR LOCAL CHEFS TO COLLABORATIVELY GROW THEIR BUSINESSES

THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION AND ADAPTIVE REUSE OF 20,000 SQUARE FEET OF THE HISTORIC FORMER WABASH YMCA BUILDING  THIS 81,000 SQUARE FEET BUILDING WAS THE FIRST HOME IN THE NORTH FOR THOUSANDS OF AFRICAN AMERICAN MEN DURING THE GREAT MIGRATION WHO HAD MOVED FROM THE SOUTH SEEKING ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY AND A REPRIEVE FROM RACIAL DISCRIMINATION  FOR THE FIRST HALF OF THE 20TH CENTURY, THE WABASH YMCA SERVED AS THE HEART OF SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC PROGRESS FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS IN CHICAGO, PROVIDING HOUSING, JOB TRAINING, MEETING SPACES, AND RECREATIONAL FACILITIES  THE BUILDING REQUIRES NEW FLOORING, LEAK REPAIRS, AND THE REPAIR OF A MURAL ENTITLED  MIND, BODY, AND SPIRIT  PAINTED BY WILLIAM EDOUARD SCOTT IN 1936  THE FORMER WABASH YMCA WILL BE USED FOR EVENTS AND ACTIVITIES FOR COMMUNITY INTERACTION AND EDUCATION

ORIGINALLY CONSTRUCTED IN 1917 AND IN OPERATION UNTIL 1964, PINE GROVE SCHOOL IN CUMBERLAND COUNTY WAS BUILT WITH THE SUPPORT OF THE JULIUS ROSENWALD FUND  LIKE MOST ROSENWALD SCHOOLS, PINE GROVE SCHOOL PROVIDED AFRICAN AMERICAN CHILDREN IN ITS RURAL, ISOLATED COMMUNITY WITH STATE OF THE ART FACILITIES AT A TIME WHEN LITTLE TO NO LOCAL PUBLIC FUNDS WERE DESIGNATED FOR THEIR EDUCATION  THE GRANT WILL FUND INITIAL STABILIZATION TO ARREST ON GOING DETERIORATION AND STRUCTURAL THREATS

GIRARD ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IS KNOWN AS AN  EQUALIZATION SCHOOL  BECAUSE IT WAS BUILT IN 1955 BY THE STATE OF GEORGIA TO IMPROVE SCHOOLS FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN CHILDREN UNDER THE  SEPARATE BUT EQUAL  DOCTRINE  THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE COLLECTION OF DETAILED BASE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PROPERTY AND BUILDING USING A LASER SURVEY, CLEANUP OF ALL UNNECESSARY MATERIALS AND ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS, AND DESIGN AND ENGINEERING STUDIES NECESSARY FOR THIS PHASE OF WORK  PLANS FOR THE SCHOOL INCLUDE SENIOR SERVICES AND ACTIVITIES, AND AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS

THE INDIANA FIRE STATION  2 IN THE NORTHSIDE NEIGHBORHOOD OF ATLANTIC CITY IS A KEY RESOURCE WITHIN THE NORTHSIDE INSTITUTIONAL HISTORIC DISTRICT  THE MAJOR GOAL OF THIS PROJECT  THE FIRST OF THREE PHASES  IS TO PRESERVE AND STABILIZE THE 100 YEAR OLD FIRE STATION S BUILDING ENVELOPE  ONCE THE BUILDING IS PROTECTED, THE SECOND AND THIRD PHASES WILL REHABILITATE THE INTERIOR TO ALLOW THE INDIANA FIREHOUSE TO CONTINUE ITS MISSION AS A FUNCTIONING 21ST CENTURY FIREHOUSE AND NORTHSIDE COMMUNITY FIXTURE  THIS PROJECT IS RECEIVING AN ADDITIONAL  1,490,429 FROM OTHER SOURCES OF FUNDING

THE TULSA RACE RIOT MASSACRE OF 1921 IN THE GREENWOOD DISTRICT IS ETCHED IN THE HISTORY OF THE CITY, THE MEMORY OF THOSE WHO SURVIVED, AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITIES NATIONALLY AND THE VERY BRICKS THEMSELVES  DENIED REPARATIONS BY THE INSURANCE COMPANY BECAUSE THE DESTRUCTION WAS LABELED  A RIOT , SURVIVORS FOUGHT A NEWLY IMPOSED ZONING REGULATION AND WON WHEN THE ORDINANCE WAS RULED UNCONSTITUTIONAL  THE BUILDINGS PRESENTED HERE FOR MUCH NEEDED REPAIR TELL A STORY OF DETERMINATION, COLLECTIVE WILL, RENEWAL, AND RESILIENCE AND ARE ALL THAT REMAINS OF THE HEART OF  BLACK WALL STREET   PHASE 2 WORK WILL REPAIR STORE FRONTS AND BRICKWORK OF THE EAST AND WEST BUILDINGS IN THE 100 BLOCK OF N  GREENWOOD AVENUE AND WILL ASSURE THAT THE STRUCTURES ARE SOUND, AND THE HISTORIC BRICKWORK IS PROTECTED  THE APPLICANT IS PROVIDING  22,000 IN ADDITIONAL FUNDS

OVER 5,000 ROSENWALD SCHOOLS WERE BUILT ACROSS THE RURAL JIM CROW SOUTH TO ADVANCE THE EDUCATION OF AFRICAN AMERICAN CHILDREN FROM 1914 1932  THROUGH THE LEADERSHIP OF BOOKER T  WASHINGTON, FOUNDER OF TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE, AND THE PHILANTHROPY OF JULIUS ROSENWALD, PRESIDENT OF SEARS AND  ROEBUCK, THE ROSENWALD FUND WAS CREATED TO BUILD SCHOOLS AND IMPROVE EDUCATION OF AFRICAN AMERICANS IN THE LARGELY SEGREGATED AND RURAL SOUTH  GRANT FUNDS WILL FOCUS ON THE MOST IMMEDIATE THREAT TO THE BUILDING S SURVIVAL, AS WELL AS ARCHITECTURAL AND STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY, THE SIGNIFICANT COLLAPSE OF THE ROOF, RAFTERS, AND FLOOR IN ONE OF THE BUILDING S CLASSROOMS

THE BLEC IS THE SITE OF THE FORMER LAKEVIEW SCHOOL, THE LAST SEGREGATED SCHOOL FOR BLACK RESIDENTS IN LEXINGTON COUNTY, SOUTH CAROLINA  REHABILITATING THIS INTERIOR SPACE WILL ALLOW THE BCCEC TO PROVIDE AFFORDABLE OFFICE, MEETING, AND TRAINING SPACE FOR SMALL, MINORITY, AND WOMEN OWNED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS  THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE FIRST PHASE OF REHABILITATION AND WILL ALLOW FOR THE RE PURPOSING AND REUSE OF APPROXIMATELY 3 4 FORMER CLASSROOMS AND ASSOCIATED HALLWAY AND STORAGE SPACE  THE FIRST PHASE WILL ALSO INCLUDE RENOVATIONS OF ADJACENT BATHROOM FACILITIES TO PROVIDE ENHANCED ADA ACCESSIBILITY

THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE EFFORTS TO PROCURE A HISTORICAL SITE ASSESSMENT AND MITIGATION PLAN FOR THE REPAIR AND PRESERVATION OF THE MIDDLE VILLAGE KIVA  THE PUEBLO OF ZUNI MIDDLE VILLAGE AREA IS RECOGNIZED AS A HISTORICAL AND RELIGIOUS PROPERTY IN DIRE NEED OF PRESERVATION  THE PEOPLE OF ZUNI ARE PUEBLOAN PEOPLE THAT ARE THE ORIGINAL INHABITANTS OF THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES, EXISTING REGIONALLY APPROXIMATELY SINCE 100 AD  MULTI LEVEL BUILDINGS WERE BUILT ABOVE GROUND TO SUPPORT STORAGE AND HOME DWELLINGS  WHILE BENEATH GROUND, SINGLE LEVEL STRUCTURES WERE CREATED TO SUPPORT PUEBLOAN CULTURAL PRACTICES, LIKE CEREMONIES, AND TRADITIONAL HEALING  THESE PLACES WERE CLASSIFIED IN THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE AS KIVA S BY EARLY SETTLERS TO THE REGION  CURRENTLY, THE ZUNI PEOPLE RELY ON THE KIVAS FOR CEREMONY TO PRODUCE CONTINUED NATURAL RESOURCES IN THE FORM OF NOURISHMENT AND OR SHELTER FOR COMMUNITY, MAKING THE KIVA AN IMPORTANT FACTOR IN THE CONTINUED EXISTENCE OF THE ZUNI CULTURE AND LANGUAGE

SINCE 1999, THE HOUSE OF RAPPAHANNOCK CHIEF GEORGE L  NELSON HAS PROVIDED PUBLIC HISTORY AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR BOTH TRIBAL CITIZENS AND THE STATEWIDE COMMUNITY  THIS GRANT WILL FUND THE REHABILITATION AND INTERPRETATION OF THIS STRUCTURE AS A TRIBAL MUSEUM AND SPIRITUAL TRADITIONAL INDIGENOUS HEALING CENTER  IT WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO EDUCATE CITIZENS AND THE PUBLIC ABOUT VIRGINIA S RICH INDIGENOUS HISTORY AND THE STRUGGLE FOR TRIBAL RIGHTS IN THE FACE OF ONE OF THE MOST ANTI INDIAN LAWS IN THE COUNTRY, THE 1924 RACIAL IDENTITY LAW

IN 1830, A BAND OF 859 POTAWATOMI WERE FORCED TO MARCH 660 MILES FROM THEIR HOME IN NORTHERN INDIANA TO A SMALL RESERVE IN PRESENT DAY KANSAS, ON A TRAIL LATER TO BE KNOWN AS THE TRAIL OF DEATH  AS MORE PEOPLE MIGRATED WEST, THEY BROUGHT DEADLY DISEASES ALONG THE TRAILS INCLUDING CHOLERA AND SMALLPOX, WHICH NEGATIVELY IMPACTED THE POTAWATOMI  A CHOLERA OUTBREAK HIT UNIONTOWN IN 1849  THE TRIBE BURNED THE TOWN TO THE GROUND TO STOP THE DISEASE FROM SPREADING  TODAY, A LARGE COTTONWOOD TREE MARKS THE MASS GRAVE OF AT LEAST 22 TO 35 POTAWATOMI WHO LOST THEIR LIVES DURING THE OUTBREAK  TO PROTECT AND CONSERVE THIS HISTORICALLY AND CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT TRIBAL ASSET AND SITE AND SHOW RESPECT AND HONOR TO THE ANCESTORS WHO HAVE PASSED ON, THE TRIBE WILL USE THIS GRANT TO REPAIR THE STONE WALLS AND RESTORE HEADSTONES AS NEEDED, RECONSTRUCT THE STONE WALL THAT CURRENTLY MARKS AND PROTECTS THE BURIAL SITE AND REPAIR HEADSTONES, AND TO CONDUCT A SURVEY USING GROUND PENETRATING RADAR  GPR   RESTORING AND PROTECTING THIS SACRED AND HISTORIC SITE IS CRITICAL TO PROTECT THE HISTORY OF THE POTAWATOMI PEOPLE

THE GOAL OF THIS GRANT IS TO BRING AWARENESS TO THE MI KMAQ CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT ART FORM OF ASH SPLINT BASKET MAKING  CURRENTLY, THE ASH TREE POPULATION IS BEING DECIMATED BY THE EMERALD ASH BORER, AN INSECT THAT FEEDS ON ITS LEAVES  ONCE THE TREES ARE GONE, THE ART OF CREATING ASH SPLINT BASKETS WILL NOT SURVIVE  THE TRIBE WILL CREATE CULTURAL DISPLAYS ABOUT THE BASKETS AND THE BUG, HOST A PUBLIC OUTDOOR BASKET MAKERS SHOWCASE  AND CREATE A DOCUMENTARY HIGHLIGHTING THE EFFECTS OF THE EMERALD ASH BORER AND DOCUMENTING SPLIT ASH BASKET MAKING, WITH INTERVIEWS FROM BASKET MAKERS

THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT INTERVIEWS WITH ORDINARY PARTICIPANTS IN THE SELMA TO MONTGOMERY MARCH OF 1965  THERE, ON MARCH 7, 1965, ALABAMA STATE TROOPERS AND DALLAS COUNTY SHERIFF S DEPUTIES ASSAULTED 600 AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS PROTESTORS ON THE SOUTHERN END OF THE EDMUND PETTUS BRIDGE, JUST SOUTH OF SELMA  THIS VIOLENT SCENE BECAME KNOWN AS BLOODY SUNDAY  THOUGH THE BRUTAL IMAGERY OF THAT DAY REMAINS SEARED IN OUR COLLECTIVE UNCONSCIOUS, WE STILL HAVE AN INCOMPLETE ACCOUNTING OF THE DAY AND ITS PARTICIPANTS  THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE ONGOING INITIATIVE TO IDENTIFY AND LOCATE THE  FOOT SOLDIERS  OF THIS LARGER GRASSROOTS EFFORT

THE LEONARD MEDICAL SCHOOL WAS THE FIRST FOUR YEAR MEDICAL SCHOOL FOR BLACK STUDENTS IN THE UNITED STATES, AND THE FIRST FOUR YEAR MEDICAL SCHOOL IN NORTH CAROLINA  THE SCHOOL INCREASED ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE FOR THE BLACK COMMUNITY THAT RESULTED FROM THE TRAINING OF BLACK DOCTORS AND CONTRIBUTED TO CREATING A BLACK PROFESSIONAL CLASS AND A GROUP OF COMMUNITY LEADERS WHO WERE POLITICALLY ACTIVE IN THE FIGHT AGAINST DISCRIMINATORY JIM CROW LAWS OF THE PERIOD  THIS GRANT WILL REHABILITATE MATERIAL COMPONENTS OF LEONARD HALL WHICH WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1883  THIS PROJECT WILL REPLACE THE OBSOLETE HEATING, VENTILATION, AND AIR CONDITIONING EQUIPMENT, SYSTEMS, AND COMPONENTS IN THE BUILDING  REPAIR, REPLACE, AND UPGRADE OF COMPONENTS OF THE LIFE SAFETY FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM, PARTICULARLY THE FIRE PUMP  AND ASSESS AND REPAIR OF THE ROOF

FUNDS AWARDED WILL SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION AND REHABILITATION OF PROPERTIES IN THE MADISON HISTORIC DISTRICT  SUBGRANTS WILL PROMOTE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT THROUGH EXTERIOR HISTORIC REHABILITATION AND PRESERVATION TO BOTH RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES

MASJID AL ANSAR, ORIGINALLY BUILT IN 1931 AND CONVERTED TO A MOSQUE IN 1966, WAS ONE IN A NETWORK OF TEMPLES ESTABLISHED DURING THE PERIOD OF THE NATION OF ISLAM  THE MOVEMENT INJECTED TWO IMPORTANT IDEAS INTO THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT, SELF SUFFICIENCY, AND RELIGIOUS PLURALISM  MASJID AL ANSAR RECORDS THE STORY OF HOW BLACK MUSLIMS WERE INSTRUMENTAL IN THE CIVIL RIGHTS CAMPAIGNS IN THE DEEP SOUTH  THE PROPOSED PROJECT INCLUDES REPAIR OF THE BUILDING S WORN ROOF, FLOORING, ACCESSIBILITY ENHANCEMENTS, AND SECURITY MEASURES  THE APPLICANT IS PROVIDING  86,980 IN ADDITIONAL FUNDS

WEST HUNTER STREET BAPTIST CHURCH WAS THE CHURCH HOME OF REV  DR  RALPH DAVID ABERNATHY DURING KEY YEARS OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT WHEN HE AND DR  MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR  LED THE SOUTHERN CHRISTIAN LEADERSHIP CONFERENCE THROUGH SELMA, BIRMINGHAM, AND SO MANY OTHER STRUGGLES  THE CHURCH WILL BE USED TO INTERPRET HISTORY FOR EDUCATION, AND FOR COMMUNITY EVENTS  FUNDS WILL BE USED TO REPLACEMISSING WINDOWSAND REFINISH PEWS AND SANCTUARY SPACE

THE MAJOR GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE NEW SYSTEMS AND BUILDING IMPROVEMENTS TO ACHIEVE CODE COMPLIANCE INCLUDING ELECTRICAL UPGRADES, FIRE PROTECTION, AND GREATER ACCESSIBILITY  THE TABERNACLE BAPTIST CHURCH EDIFICE WILL BE 100 YEARS OLD IN 2022 AND HOLDS NATIONAL SIGNIFICANCE DUE TO ITS SIGNIFICANT ASSOCIATIONS WITH THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT IN SELMA, FROM 1922 TO 1968, ESPECIALLY THE MINISTRY OF REV  D  V  JEMISON

REVEREND OLIVER BROWN, LEAD LITIGANT IN THE BROWN V  BOARD OF EDUCATION CASE, WAS PASTOR AT ST  MARK S AME CHURCH  DURING THAT TIME REV  BROWN AND THE CHURCH HOSTED LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS WHO TIRELESSLY WORKED THE CASE THROUGH THE U S  SUPREME COURT  THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO PRESERVE THE CHURCH AS A PLACE BASED LEARNING FACILITY FOR NOT ONLY TOPEKA RESIDENTS, BUT FOR VISITING TOURISTS AND SCHOLARS  THIS GRANT WILL FUND MASONRY REPAIR, TERMITE DAMAGE ROT TO WOOD STRUCTURES, WINDOW REPAIR, AND THE CONSTRUCTION OF ADA COMPLIANT RESTROOMS AND ACCESSIBLE KITCHEN SPACE
FREEDOM RIDES MUSEUM INTERIOR EXHIBIT PLAN   PHASE III   ORIENTATION

IN 1860 THE CLOTILDA ILLEGALLY TRANSPORTED 110 PEOPLE FROM BENIN, AFRICA TO MOBILE, ALABAMA, MORE THAN 50 YEARS AFTER THE UNITED STATES BANNED THE IMPORTATION OF ENSLAVED PEOPLE TO THE COUNTRY  THE SHIP WAS THEN INTENTIONALLY BURNED, SUNK, AND ABANDONED IN THE MOBILE RIVER BY THE CRIMINALS WHO WERE TRYING TO EVADE AUTHORITIES  THE WRECK OF CLOTILDA WAS IDENTIFIED IN 2018 2019 AND WAS FORMALLY LISTED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER ON NOVEMBER 8, 2021  THE STABILIZATION PROJECT WILL INCLUDE SONAR SURVEY TO PROVIDE UPDATED AND DETAILED IMAGERY OF THE VESSEL  A MARINE GEOLOGICAL STUDY  A BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT  AND TARGETED ARCHAEOLOGICAL TESTING TO INVESTIGATE THE WRECK ITSELF  THE STATE WILL PROVIDE  71,724 IN ADDITIONAL FUNDS FOR THE PROJECT

ST  PAUL UNITED METHODIST CHURCH IS A CONTRIBUTING PROPERTY IN THE BIRMINGHAM CIVIL RIGHTS HISTORIC DISTRICT  THE DISTRICT IS DIRECTLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT IN THE 20TH CENTURY  THIS FOURTH PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS INFRASTRUCTURE, MECHANICAL AND PLUMBING PRIORITIES INCLUDING THE ADDITION OF AN ADA COMPLIANT RESTROOM  THE APPLICANT WILL PROVIDE  20,000 IN MATCHING FUNDS

THE ACE THEATER WAS BUILT IN THE 1930S BY WOMETCO ENTERPRISES AS A  COLORED ONLY  JIM CROW MOVIE THEATER COMMUNITY VENUE IN WEST GROVE, MIAMI  IN 1979 IT WAS SOLD TO A LOCAL BLACK BUSINESSMAN, HARVEY WALLACE, AND UNDER HIS STEWARDSHIP THE BUILDING CONTINUED TO PLAY A ROLE IN THE COMMUNITY  THE ACE THEATER FUNCTIONED AS A COMMUNITY VENUE FOR MOVIES, GRADUATIONS, PROMS, CLOSED CIRCUIT BOXING MATCHES, AND CONCERTS  FUNDING WILL BE USED FOR A PRESERVATION AND REHABILITATION  ADAPTIVE REUSE PLAN INCLUDING A NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION  ADDITIONAL WORK INCLUDES ADA ACCESSIBILITY, INSTALLATION OF A HVAC SYSTEM, SAFETY SPRINKLER SYSTEM, AND NEW ELECTRICAL SYSTEM

HISTORIC ALPHA LODGE NO. 116 OF THE FREE & ACCEPTED MASONS, THE CHAPTER'S LODGE SINCE 1978, WAS DAMAGED BY HURRICANE IDA. IT IS THE HOME TO THE FIRST (ALPHA) AFRICAN AMERICAN LODGE OF THE MASONIC ORDER IN NEW JERSEY, ESTABLISHED IN 1871 WHEN 9 BLACK MEN WERE DENIED ENTRY INTO THEIR LOCAL LODGE. THIS GRANT WILL FUND ARCHITECTURAL PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS FOR FUTURE PRESERVATION OF THE RESOURCE.

A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK, THE LEMOYNE HOUSE WAS THE RESIDENCE OF DR. FRANCIS JULIUS LEMOYNE. BUILT IN 1812, THE LEMOYNE HOUSE WAS THE CENTER OF HIS POLITICAL ACTIVITY WITH THE ABOLITION MOVEMENT AND THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD. THIS GRANT WILL PRESERVE THE HOUSE BY REPAIRING ITS WINDOWS, SHUTTERS, FRONT STEPS, AND ROOF.

TAWAWA CHIMNEY CORNER WAS THE RESIDENCE OF TWO AFRICAN METHODIST EPISCOPAL CHURCH BISHOPS ACTIVE IN THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT. REV. BENJAMIN W. ARNETT WAS AN OHIO LEGISLATOR AND ADVISOR TO WILLIAM MCKINLEY. REV. REVEDY C. RANSOM WAS A FOUNDER OF THE BLACK SOCIAL GOSPEL MOVEMENT AND DELIVERED THE OPENING PRAYER AT THE 1940 DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL CONVENTION. THIS GRANT WILL REHABILITATE THE RESIDENCE WITH REPAIRS TO THE EXTERIOR ENVELOPE.

WINSBOROUGH HALL IS NAMED FOR HALLIE PAXSON WINSBOROUGH, SECRETARY OF THE WOMEN'S AUXILIARY OF THE SOUTHERN PRESBYTERIAN GENERAL ASSEMBLY. AN ADVOCATE FOR TRAINING AND DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AT STILLMAN INSTITUTE AND ACROSS THE NATION, HALLIE PAXSON WINSBOROUGH WAS A CRITICAL ORGANIZER OF THE FIRST COLORED WOMEN'S CONFERENCE AND FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE WOMEN'S DORMITORY THAT BEARS HER NAME. THIS GRANT WILL REPAIR THE ROOF, WINDOWS, AND COLUMNS OF THE HISTORIC DORMITORY.

THE VERNON SCHOOL IS NAMED FOR THE AFRICAN METHODIST EPISCOPAL BISHOP WHO LOBBIED FOR ITS FUNDING AND SPOKE AT ITS OPENING IN 1936. THIS HISTORIC SCHOOL OF AFRICAN AMERICAN EDUCATION IS CURRENTLY A COMMUNITY CENTER. THIS GRANT WILL FUND EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR REHABILITATION OF THE VERNON SCHOOL FOR CONTINUED USE.

SINCE 1816 THE FARMINGTON QUAKER MEETINGHOUSE WAS A CENTER FOR EQUAL RIGHTS FOR ALL PEOPLE, ESPECIALLY NATIVE AMERICANS, AFRICAN AMERICANS, AND WOMEN. IN 1927, THE MEETINGHOUSE WAS SOLD AND CONVERTED INTO A BARN. THIS GRANT WILL PRESERVE THE EXTERIOR ENVELOPE AND RESTORE THE INTERIOR.

POTTER'S FIELD, AN INDIGENT CEMETERY IN CINCINNATI, IS A SIGNIFICANT SITE OF UNEQUAL BURIAL RIGHTS. AN ESTIMATED 20,000 PEOPLE WERE BURIED AT POTTER'S FIELD, BETWEEN 1852 AND 1981. THE EXACT NUMBER IS NOT KNOWN BECAUSE BURIAL MARKERS WERE ONLY USED BETWEEN 1960 AND 1964, JUST ONE INDICATION OF THE SEVERE DISPARITY UNDER WHICH THE BODIES OF THE CITY'S INDIGENT DEAD WERE BURIED VERSES THOSE WITH WEALTH. THIS GRANT WILL SURVEY AND LOCATE THE GRAVES AS A VITAL STEP IN PRE-PRESERVATION PLANNING OF THE HISTORIC CEMETERY.

THE CAMPUS OF FLORA MACDONALD COLLEGE IS A MONUMENT TO WOMEN'S EDUCATION. BUILT BETWEEN 1900 AND 1910 THE CAMPUS STILL OPERATES AS AN EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION IT WAS FOUNDED IN 1896 BY DR. CHARLES GRAVES VARDELL AS THE RED SPRINGS SEMINARY, RENAMED SOUTHERN PRESBYTERIAN COLLEGE AND CONSERVATORY OF MUSIC IN 1903, THEN FLORA MACDONALD COLLEGE IN 1914 WHICH OPERATED UNTIL 1961. THE SITE STILL SUPPORTS EDUCATION BY HOUSING A PRE-K THROUGH 12 PREPARATORY SCHOOL. THIS GRANT WILL PRESERVE THE HISTORIC CAMPUS BY REPAIRING THE MASONRY AND WINDOWS.

ST. PAUL UNITED METHODIST CHURCH IS LISTED AS A CONTRIBUTING PROPERTY IN THE BIRMINGHAM CIVIL RIGHTS HISTORIC DISTRICT. THIS DISTRICT IS DIRECTLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT IN THE 20TH CENTURY. THIS IS THE FIFTH PHASE OF THE PROJECT FUNDED BY NPS, AND IT WILL ADDRESS ELECTRICAL AND FIRE SAFETY UPGRADES TO ALLOW CONTINUED SAFE USE OF THE HISTORIC STRUCTURE.

THE ELEANOR B. RAINEY MEMORIAL INSTITUTE BUILDING IS CLEVELAND'S ONLY REMAINING SETTLEMENT HOUSE. BUILT IN 1904, THE INSTITUTE HOUSED MIDDLE-CLASS SETTLERS WHO PROVIDED EDUCATIONAL AND SOCIAL SERVICES TO CLEVELAND'S IMMIGRANT AND MINORITY COMMUNITIES AS ONE HOUSE OF THE REFORMIST SETTLEMENT HOUSE MOVEMENT. THE RAINEY INSTITUTE OWNED AND CONTINUOUSLY OPERATED THE HOUSE UNTIL 2011. THIS GRANT PROJECT WILL FUND THE REHABILITATION OF THE HOUSE TO ENABLE ITS CONTINUED USE AS A COMMUNITY CENTER.

HISTORIC SURVEY AND INVENTORY OF TACOMA'S BLACK HERITAGETHE HILLTOP NEIGHBORHOOD OF TACOMA IS THE CENTER OF ITS BLACK COMMUNITY, YET DESPITE BLACK RESIDENTS COMPRISING 11% OF TACOMA'S POPULATION, ONLY ONE STRUCTURE IN TACOMA IS LISTED FOR ITS SIGNIFICANCE TO BLACK HISTORY. THIS GRANT WILL SURVEY AND DOCUMENT HISTORIC RESOURCES OF BLACK HISTORY IN THE HILLTOP NEIGHBORHOOD AND NOMINATE SEVERAL OF THESE PROPERTIES TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH OVER $12,000 TO THE PROJECT.

SURVEY OF AFRICAN AMERICAN SCHOOLS IN ALABAMAEDUCATION FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS IN ALABAMA WAS SYSTEMATICALLY LIMITED OVER TIME STARTING WITH ANTI-LITERACY LAWS PASSED IN 1832, AND CONTINUED TO BE A STRUGGLE EVEN AFTER THE 1954 BROWN V. BOARD OF EDUCATION DECISION. THE MOST COMMON SCHOOL TYPES ASSOCIATED WITH THESE PERIODS ARE COUNTY TRAINING SCHOOLS AND EQUALIZATION SCHOOLS WHICH WERE SEEN AS AN EQUALIZING SOLUTION TO AVOID DESEGREGATION. THESE SCHOOLS ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN ALABAMA'S LISTINGS IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THIS GRANT WILL COMPLETE A MULTIPLE PROPERTY DOCUMENTATION FORM AND NOMINATE SEVERAL SCHOOL PROPERTIES UNDER ITS FRAMEWORK TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES.

DENVER AMERICAN INDIAN AND INDIGENOUS PEOPLES HISTORIC CONTEXTTHE 2010 U.S. CENSUS IDENTIFIED OVER 22,000 AMERICAN INDIAN AND INDIGENOUS PEOPLES LIVING IN DENVER AND REPRESENTING OVER 100 TRIBES. HOWEVER, THE CITY HAS ZERO AMERICAN INDIAN AND INDIGENOUS PEOPLES HISTORIC RESOURCES LISTED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THIS GRANT WILL DEVELOP A HISTORIC CONTEXT REPORT FOR SIGNIFICANT AMERICAN INDIAN AND INDIGENOUS PEOPLES HISTORIC RESOURCES AND NOMINATE AT LEAST ONE RESOURCE TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH $52,500 TO THE PROJECT.

PATHWAYS TO NATIONAL REGISTER RECOGNITION FOR CLEVELAND'S BLACK CHURCHESWITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE CLEVELAND RESTORATION SOCIETY, THE OHIO HISTORICAL SOCIETY HAS IDENTIFIED 20 UNDERREPRESENTED BLACK CHURCHES IN CLEVELAND, OHIO. THESE CHURCHES ARE SIGNIFICANT FOR A VARIETY OF THEMES SUCH AS HISTORIC CONGREGATIONS, CIVIL RIGHTS, AND ARCHITECTURE. THIS GRANT WILL SURVEY 20 BLACK CHURCHES IN CLEVELAND AND NOMINATE UP TO 20 BLACK CHURCHES TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES, INCLUDING LIBERTY HILL BAPTIST CHURCH.

ATLANTIC BEACH NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATIONATLANTIC BEACH IS THE ONLY INDEPENDENTLY OWNED AND GOVERNED HISTORICALLY AFRICAN AMERICAN OCEAN FRONT COMMUNITY ON THE EAST COAST. IN 1934, ATLANTIC BEACH WAS FOUNDED BY AFRICAN AMERICANS AND GULLAH GEECHEE WHO WERE DENIED ACCESS TO WHITE PUBLIC BEACHES BY JIM CROW SEGREGATION. THIS GRANT WILL SURVEY AND NOMINATE THE ATLANTIC BEACH HISTORIC DISTRICT TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES.

CHESTERTOWN HISTORIC DISTRICT: ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTATIONIN 1966, CHESTERTOWN HISTORIC DISTRICT WAS LISTED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES, AND IN 1984 THE BOUNDARIES OF THE DISTRICT WERE INCREASED. HOWEVER, THE ORIGINAL AND EXPANDED NOMINATION DID NOT INCLUDE THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF AFRICAN AMERICANS TO THE DISTRICT'S SIGNIFICANCE. THIS GRANT WILL UPDATE THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES NOMINATION FOR THE CHESTERTOWN HISTORIC DISTRICT TO INCLUDE THE AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY MISSING FROM THE CURRENT NOMINATION. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH $13,250 TO THE PROJECT.

NORTH CAROLINA GREEN BOOK PROPERTIES DOCUMENTATION AND NOMINATIONTHE GREEN BOOK WAS AN ANNUAL GUIDEBOOK FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN TRAVELERS, PUBLISHED FROM 1936-1966, WHICH PROVIDED A RELIABLE LIST OF ESTABLISHMENTS THAT WOULD WELCOME BUSINESS FROM AFRICAN AMERICANS. NORTH CAROLINA HAD APPROXIMATELY 327 SITES IN THE GREEN BOOK, AND IT IS ESTIMATED THAT AT LEAST 50% OF THOSE SITES NO LONGER EXIST. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A SURVEY OF GREEN BOOK SITES, COMPETE A STATEWIDE THEMATIC MULTIPLE PROPERTY DOCUMENTATION FORM, AND CREATE AN INDIVIDUAL NOMINATION FOR THE MAGNOLIA HOUSE, WHICH WAS A GREEN BOOK TOURIST HOME IN GREENSBORO. THE GRANTEE WILL CONTRIBUTE $5,000 TOWARDS THE PROJECT.

DIEGO SALAS SABLAN HOUSE NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATIONTHIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE GUAM HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE TO CONDUCT A SURVEY AND NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION FOR THE DIEGO SALAS SABLAN HOUSE. BUILT IN 1955 AS A SELF-CONSTRUCTED HOUSE, IT IS ALSO SIGNIFICANT AS THE HOUSE OF SABLAN'S GRANDSON, JOHNNY SABLAN, A FAMOUS CHAMORU ENTERTAINER AND GUAM'S FIRST ARTIST TO PRODUCE AN ALL-CHAMORU MUSIC ALBUM PROMOTING AND PERPETUATING THE CHAMORU LANGUAGE.

CHINESE AMERICAN EXCLUSION IN WASHINGTON STATETHE CHINESE EXCLUSION ACT WAS PASSED IN 1882 AND WAS THE FIRST FEDERAL LAW TO SPECIFICALLY EXCLUDE AN ENTIRE ETHNIC GROUP FROM IMMIGRATING TO THE US, BUT DESPITE THIS, WASHINGTON S CHINESE AMERICAN COMMUNITY SHOWED RESILIENCE AND PERSEVERANCE  UNFORTUNATELY, THE HISTORY OF THE EXCLUSION ERA FROM 1882 1963 HAS LARGELY GONE UNDOCUMENTED, AND MANY OF THE SIGNIFICANT SITES RELATED TO THAT HISTORY ARE ALREADY GONE  THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A SURVEY OF EXISTING SITES RELATED TO THE CHINESE AMERICAN EXCLUSION ERA, DEVELOPMENT OF A HISTORIC CONTEXT, AND RESULT IN AT LEAST ONE NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION, AS WELL AS SERVING AS A FOUNDATION FOR FUTURE NOMINATIONS OF CHINESE AMERICAN RELATED PROPERTIES  THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH THIS PROJECT WITH  12,500

HISTORICAL AFRICAN AMERICAN NEIGHBORHOOD SURVEYSAN ANTONIO CURRENTLY HAS A DEARTH OF FEDERAL AND STATE DESIGNATED HISTORIC PROPERTIES IN ASSOCIATION WITH THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY. FOCUSING ON FIVE AREAS NEAR DOWNTOWN WHICH HAVE LARGELY BEEN UNTOUCHED BY URBAN RENEWAL AND MODERN REDEVELOPMENT, THIS PROJECT WILL SURVEY 19TH TO 20TH CENTURY PROPERTIES, AND LEAD TO AT LEAST ONE NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION ASSOCIATED WITH AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY.

HISTORIC CONTEXT OF THE MIDDLE EASTERN COMMUNITYTHE DETROIT CITY COUNCIL'S HISTORIC DESIGNATION ADVISORY BOARD HAS DEVELOPED A MULTI-YEAR INITIATIVE TO DOCUMENT AND HIGHLIGHT UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES IN DETROIT. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THIS INITIATIVE BY DEVELOPING A HISTORIC CONTEXT FOR THE MIDDLE EASTERN COMMUNITY IN DETROIT, NOMINATE AT LEAST ONE PROPERTY ASSOCIATED WITH MIDDLE EASTERN HISTORY, AND WORK WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS ON EDUCATION AND OUTREACH REGARDING THIS HISTORY. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH WITH $15,000 TOWARDS THE PROJECT.

MULTIPLE PROPERTY SUBMISSION FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS IN RHODE ISLAND IN 2019, WITH AN AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS GRANT, THE RHODE ISLAND STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE COMPLETED A STATEWIDE SURVEY OF 20TH CENTURY AFRICAN AMERICAN CIVIL RIGHTS SITES, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE RHODE ISLAND HISTORICAL SOCIETY. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE SHPO TO UNDERTAKE RESEARCH INTO PRE-20TH CENTURY AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY, EVALUATE THEIR NATIONAL REGISTER ELIGIBILITY, AND NOMINATE FOUR OF THOSE PROPERTIES TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER IN ORDER TO GAIN A MORE COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF RHODE ISLAND'S AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY.

RAFAEL RIVERA HISTORIC CONTEXT AND SURVEYRAFAEL RIVERA IS ONE OF THE EASTERN NEIGHBORHOODS OF DOWNTOWN LAS VEGAS AND WITH A LARGELY LATINX COMMUNITY. THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE A HISTORIC CONTEXT FOR THE NEIGHBORHOOD, COMPLETE A RECONNAISSANCE LEVEL SURVEY, AND COMPLETE AT LEAST ONE NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION. THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE FIRST OF SUCH PROJECTS IN LAS VEGAS AND WILL HELP ESTABLISH A FRAMEWORK FOR FUTURE SURVEYS FOR DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES WITHIN LAS VEGAS.

DOCUMENTING MONTANA'S CHINESE AMERICAN HISTORIC SITESOF THE 1,228 MONTANA RESOURCES LISTED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES IN MONTANA ONLY ONE CONTEXTUALIZES THE SIGNIFICANCE OF CHINESE AMERICAN HISTORY. THIS GRANT WILL COMPLETE A MULTIPLE DOCUMENTATION PROPERTY FORM AND NOMINATE 7 PROPERTIES TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH $8,600 TO THE PROJECT.

AMENDMENT TO THE DRY LAKES PLATEAU ARCHAEOLOGICAL DISTRICTTHE DRY LAKES PLATEAU IS A UNIQUE ZONE SIGNIFICANT TO THE HUMAN OCCUPATION DURING THE MIDDLE HOLOCENE PERIOD. IN 2002, THE LAND WAS LISTED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES, BUT THE BOUNDARIES DID NOT INCLUDE TWO SIGNIFICANT PARCELS. THIS PROJECT WILL AMEND THE DRY LAKES PLATEAU LISTING IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES TO ADD TWO ADDITIONAL PARCELS OF LAND AND BROADENING THE DOCUMENTED SIGNIFICANCE IN THE NOMINATION. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH $15,220 TO THE PROJECT.

KCHI PONTEGOK- REVISTING THE HISTORIC LANDSCAPE OF THE BELLOWS FALLS PETROGLYPHSPETROGLYPH SITES ARE SIGNIFICANT SACRED SITES TO THE INDIGENOUS WESTERN ABENAKI LOCATED IN VERMONT. THESE SITES ARE THE NEXUS OF HISTORICAL AND MODERN SOCIAL AND SPIRITUAL REALMS AND FEW ARE IDENTIFIED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THIS GRANT WILL UPDATE THE BELLOWS FALLS ISLAND LISTING IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES TO INCLUDE THE BELLOWS FALLS PETROGLYPH SITE. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH $12,600 TO THE PROJECT.

PALA MISSION ASISTENCIA NATIONAL REGISTER PROJECTTHE SAN ANTONIO DE PALA ASISTENCIA, ALSO KNOWN AS THE PALA MISSION COMPLEX, IS A SIGNIFICANT HISTORIC PROPERTY OF BOTH TRADITIONAL RELIGIOUS AND CULTURAL BELIEFS AND PRACTICES OF THE PALA PEOPLE LAYERED WITH THE CONTACT BETWEEN PALA PEOPLE AND COLONIAL SETTLERS, GOVERNMENTS, AND SOCIETIES. THE PALA MISSION IS RECOGNIZED AS A STATE HISTORIC LANDMARK BUT ONLY WITH A FOCUS ON EURO-AMERICAN HISTORIES, GEOGRAPHIES, AND VALUES. NO COLONIAL MISSION PERIOD PROPERTIES OF PALA ARE LISTED IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES. THIS GRANT WILL SURVEY AND NOMINATE THE PALA MISSION TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES.

FERRY STREET HISTORIC DISTRICT SURVEY AND NOMINATIONWHILE AN EFFORT HAS BEEN MADE IN THE METRO DETROIT AREA TO EXPAND THE INCLUSION OF AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY, VERY LITTLE HAS BEEN DONE IN OTHER AREAS OF THE STATE. THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE A HISTORIC CONTEXT STUDY, INTENSIVE LEVEL SURVEY, AND A NATIONAL REGISTER DISTRICT NOMINATION FOR THE FERRY STREET HISTORIC DISTRICT IN NILES, MI. ESTABLISHED IN 1846, FERRY STREET IS ONE OF MICHIGAN'S OLDEST AFRICAN AMERICAN SETTLEMENTS, REPRESENTING 1846-1900 WHEN ABOLITIONISM HELPED TO END SLAVERY AND THE FIRST CIVIL RIGHTS LEGISLATION WAS PASSED DURING RECONSTRUCTION.

THE HISTORY OF LATINO COMMUNITIES IN DC: A CONTEXT STUDYAS PART OF A SERIES OF HISTORIC CONTEXT STUDIES COVERING VARIOUS UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES, THE DC STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE WILL RESEARCH AND DOCUMENT LATINO HISTORY TO PRODUCE A HISTORIC CONTEXT STUDY. THIS HISTORIC CONTEXT STUDY WILL SERVE AS THE BASIS FOR EVALUATING PROPERTIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE LATINO COMMUNITY IN DC FOR LISTING IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER. AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, AT LEAST TWO NEW NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATIONS WILL BE PRODUCED, AND ONE EXISTING NOMINATION WILL BE AMENDED TO INCLUDE ITS LATINO SIGNIFICANCE. THE GRANTEE WILL MATCH OVER $21,000 TO THIS PROJECT.

AFRICAN AMERICAN SURVEY AND NOMINATIONIN COOPERATION WITH THE SOUTH CAROLINA AFRICAN AMERICAN HERITAGE COMMISSION, THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING NOMINATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY IN COUNTIES AND RURAL COMMUNITIES WITH TWO OR FEWER AFRICAN AMERICAN LISTED PROPERTIES. UP TO 7 NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATIONS WILL BE COMPLETED TO HELP EXPAND AFRICAN AMERICAN REPRESENTATION, WHICH IS CURRENTLY LESS THAN 10% OF THE STATE'S LISTINGS.

ZUNI ADDITIONS TO CHACO CULTURE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK, AZTEC RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT, AND SALMON RUINSTHIS PROJECT WILL UPDATE THE LISTINGS FOR 3 SITES, CHACO CULTURE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK, SALMON RUIN, AND AZTEC RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT TO INCLUDE ZUNI SIGNIFICANCE. THIS WILL INCLUDE INTERVIEWS WITH ZUNI LEADERS, DOCUMENTATION OF TRADITIONAL RELIGIOUS AND CULTURAL PRACTICES, AND EXPANDING THE NOMINATIONS PAST TRADITIONAL WESTERN VALUES TO INCLUDE BOTH PAST AND PRESENT ZUNI CULTURAL VALUES.

UTAH LATINX HISTORIC CONTEXT EXPANSION (1942-1975)IN 2018, THE UTAH DIVISION OF STATE HISTORY RECEIVED AN UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITY GRANT FOR PHASE 1 OF THEIR LATINX HISTORY PROJECT (1776-1942). PHASE 2 WILL COVER THE MISSING TIME PERIOD OF 1942-1975 BASED OFF COMMUNITY FEEDBACK REQUESTING THAT ADDITIONAL ATTENTION TO THIS PERIOD OF HISTORY. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE EXISTING HISTORIC CONTEXT AND LATINX MULTIPLE PROPERTY DOCUMENTATION AND NOMINATE AT LEAST ONE NEWLY IDENTIFIED PROPERTY TO THE NATIONAL REGISTER. LATINX PEOPLES COMPRISE THE LARGEST MINORITY GROUP IN UTAH AND ARE ONE OF THE FASTEST GROWING POPULATIONS IN THE STATE, HOWEVER PRIOR TO THE 2018 PHASE 1 PROJECT, THEIR HISTORY WAS LARGELY MISSING FROM THE NATIONAL REGISTER LISTINGS IN UTAH.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE GRANTS TO THPOS FOR THE IDENTIFICATION, EVALUATION, AND PROTECTION OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES BY SUCH MEANS AS  SURVEY, PLANNING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATION, EXPANSION OF THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES, AND TO ASSIST THPOS IN CARRYING OUT THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACTIVITIES THAT THE TRIBE AGREED TO ASSUME FROM THE STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE, ON TRIBAL LANDS, UNDER THEIR PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE  AWARDS UNDER THIS PROGRAM MUST COMPLY WITH AND SUPPORT 54 USC 301 ET SEQ   COMMONLY KNOWN AS THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT OF 1966, AS AMENDED

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES AUTHORIZED BY THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT  NHPA  FOR GRANTS TO STATES  STATES WILL COMPLETE PROJECT WORK IN 8 PROGRAM AREAS, ASAPPLICABLE AS DEFINED IN THE NHPA  A MINIMUM OF 10 0  OF THE AWARD MUST BE SUBGRANTEDTO COMMUNITIES PARTICIPATING IN THE CERTIFIED LOCAL GOVERNMENT PROGRAM, AS APPLICABLE

THE PENOBSCOT NATION MAINTAINS A CULTURAL, HISTORIC, RELIGIOUS AND SPIRITUAL INTEREST IN ITS ABORIGINALTERRITORIES. THE PURPOSE OF THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER IS TO PRESERVE, PROTECT AND MANAGE THECULTURAL RESOURCES OF THE PENOBSCOT NATION.PENOBSCOT NATION THPO GOALS1. TO PRESERVE THE CULTURAL HERITAGE OF THE PENOBSCOT PEOPLE FOR THE PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS2. TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF PENOBSCOT CULTURE AND HISTORY AMONG TRIBAL MEMBERS AS WELL AS THE MEMBERS OF THEGENERAL PUBLIC3. TO ASSURE CONTINUITY IN TRADITIONAL TRIBAL LIFE AND PRACTICES4. TO MANAGE THE CULTURAL RESOURCES OF THE PENOBSCOT NATION IN A WAY THAT IS RESPECTFUL TO PENOBSCOT TRADITIONSAND VALUES.PROGRAM AREA: ADMINISTRATION - THPO SERVES AS THE POINT OF CONTACT FOR ALL ISSUE RELATED TO THE TRIBE'S HISTORICAND CULTURAL PROPERTIES AND RESOURCES.PROGRAM AREA: SECTION 106 REVIEW - THPO WILL CONTINUE TO REVIEW FEDERAL UNDERTAKINGS FOR SECTION 106 COMPLIANCE.PROGRAM AREA: FEDERAL CONSULTATION - THPO WILL CONSULT WITH AT LEAST 5 FEDERAL AGENCIES THIS YEAR TO REVIEWCULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT POLICIES AND CONSULTATION PROTOCOLS FOR SECTION 106 COMPLIANCE.PROGRAM AREA: TRIBAL LAND ASSIGNMENTS - THPO WILL CONDUCT ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEYS AND REVIEW LAND ASSIGNMENTS FORSENSITIVE AREAS.PROGRAM AREA: EDUCATION OUTREACH - THPO WILL CONDUCT PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ON AT LEAST 10 OCCASION.PROGRAM AREA: FUNDRAISING/REVENUE GENERATION - THPO WILL CONTINUE TO SEEK GRANTS AND CONTRACT MONIES TOSUPPLEMENT DEFICITS IN THE THPO BUDGET.

THE ORGANIZED VILLAGE OF KAKE WILL CONTINUE TO OPERATE A TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE WHICH THE TRIBALHISTORIC OFFICER OPERATES AND PARTICIPATES MEANINGFULLY IN THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROGRAM TO PROTECTOUR CULTURAL RESOURCES FROM ADVERSE IMPACTS WHILE UPHOLDING OVK AND KAKE TRADITIONAL TRIBAL VALUES.

THE CULTURAL DEPARTMENT HAS A CONTINUING NEED FOR THE THPO GRANT WHICH PROVIDES ESSENTIAL FUNDING USED TO TO ASSESS CULTURAL HISTORIC SITES FOR VALUE TO THE TRIBE INCLUDING FOR TRADITIONAL FOODS AND MEDICINAL PLANTS AVAILABILITY, USAGE, AND AWARENESS AS WELL AS TO IDENTIFY ANY OBSTACLES THAT PREVENT TRIBAL MEMBERS FROM UTILIZING THESE RESOURCES. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT SUPPORTS SURVEY WORK AND ASSESSMENT OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND HISTORIC PROPERTY PROJECTS THAT MEET NPS OBJECTIVES AND FOR DOCUMENTING CULTURAL TRADITIONS AND PRESERVATION PLANNING, INCLUDING STAFF TIME AND FRINGE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS WORK.

THE MANZANITA THPO FOR 2022-2023 IS TO CONTINUE A STUDY THAT HELPS DEFINE THE GEOGRAPHIC BOUNDARIES OF THETRADITIONAL HOMELAND OF THE MANZANITA PEOPLE. THIS INCLUDES THE LANDS WITHIN THE RESERVATION AS WELL AS ANY NEWLYACQUIRED TRUST LAND. THIS STUDY WILL BE CONDUCTED USING MAPS, GIS, PHOTOGRAPHS, ETHNOGRAPHIC RECORDS, AND SITEVISITS. THIS STUDY CORRESPONDS WITH THPO PROGRAM PLAN AREAS A, B, AND C. THE RESERVATION AND TRUST LAND UNDERMANZANITA THPO JURISDICTION ARE ALSO SUBJECT TO SECTION 106 CONSULTATIONS WHICH CORRESPOND WITH PROGRAM PLANAREAS E, F, AND H.

FOLLOWING ADMINISTRATIVE CHANGES, THE COUSHATTA TRIBE HAS MADE A CONTINUOUS EFFORT TO REDEFINE THE SCOPE OF THECOMMUNITY RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE COUSHATTA TRIBAL MEMBERS AND THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE. THEPRIMARY GOAL DEFINED BY NEW THPO LEADERSHIP IS TO ENSURE THAT THE OFFICE IS PROPERLY STAFFED AND TRAINED TOFULFILL THE PRIMARY GOAL OF GREATER HISTORIC PRESERVATION. FOLLOWING EXTENSIVE EXAMINATION OF THPO ACTIVITIES INTHE PAST, THE CURRENT COUSHATTA LEADERSHIP SEEKS TO ENSURE THAT COUSHATTA HISTORY IS BOTH PRESERVED AND STUDIEDIN AN OBJECTIVE, COMMUNITY-ORIENTED CURRICULUM. IT IS THE BELIEF OF THIS ACTING THPO THAT THIS BEGINS WITH ATRADITIONAL THPO STAFF THAT CONSISTS OF ADEQUATELY TRAINED TRIBAL MEMBERS.

THE MISSION OF THE CULTURE & HERITAGE DEPARTMENT OF THE BURNS PAIUTE TRIBE IS TO PROTECT OUR ANCESTORS ANDHERITAGE WHILE AT THE SAME TIME REVITALIZING OUR LANGUAGE AND TRADITIONAL CULTURE.FY 2022 PLANNING ACTIVITIES INCLUDING THE 5TH YEAR OF A FIVE-YEAR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES COURSE OF ACTION FOR THEBURNS PAIUTE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE. IN FY 2022, THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE ENDEAVORSTO CONTINUE IMPROVING RECORDS MANAGEMENT CAPACITY AND PERFORM REVIEW AND COMPLIANCE FOR ALL UNDERTAKING WITHINTRUST LANDS OF THE BURNS PAIUTE TRIBE.SURVEY AND INVENTORY DURING FY 2022 WILL INCLUDE CULTURAL PEDESTRIAN SURVEY OF UP TO TWENTY-FIVE (25) ACRES OFTRUST LANDS AND CULTURAL INVENTORY OF UP TO SIX (6) CULTURAL SITE LOCATIONS. SURVEY WILL OCCUR IN AREAS THAT AREPROPOSED FOR FUTURE UNDERTAKINGS AND/OR WHICH MAY BE AT RISK DAMAGE FROM LOOTING OR ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION.REVIEW AND COMPLIANCE ACTIVITIES IN FY 2022 WILL INCLUDE GENERAL REVIEW AND COMPLIANCE REVIEW ASSOCIATED WITHSMALL SCALE TRUST LAND UNDERTAKINGS. REVIEW & COMPLIANCE PROCESSING OF VARIOUS TRUST LANDS UNDERTAKING BYCULTURE & HERITAGE DEPARTMENT STAFF AND OTHERS AS NEEDED.A NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION FOR AT LEAST ONE MULTICOMPONENT CULTURAL LANDSCAPE WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN 2022.THE "OLD CAMP" HISTORIC PAIUTE RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT WILL BE THE SUBJECT OF THE NOMINATION.PLANNED ACTIVITIES FOR THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE INCLUDE: ESTABLISHING ATRIBAL RESEARCHER ACCESSIBLE DOCUMENT ARCHIVE (YEAR FIVE OF FIVE). THE BURNS PAIUTE THPO IS ALSO SEEKINGAPPROVAL AS A FEDERALLY APPROVED REPOSITORY AND IS WORKING WITH AGENCIES THAT MANAGE LANDS WITHIN OUR ABORIGINALTERRITORY TO HOUSE THEIR ARCHAEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS AT THE BURNS PAIUTE REPOSITORY.EDUCATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDE TRAINING STAFF AND TRIBAL COUNCIL IN TRIBAL CULTURAL MANAGEMENT PROCESSES; THPOTRAINING AND MEETINGS. THE BURNS PAIUTE TRIBE'S CULTURE & HERITAGE DEPARTMENT WILL HOLD A WEEK-LONG TRAININGSESSION IN CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT LAW, POLICY, AND PRACTICE, FOR STAFF AND PARTICIPATING TRIBALLEGISLATORS. CULTURE & HERITAGE DEPARTMENT STAFF WILL ATTEND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT TRAINING TO FURTHERTHEIR SPECIALIZATION ON PROTECTING CULTURAL RESOURCES. THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER AND/OR THECULTURE & HERITAGE DEPARTMENT DIRECTOR WILL ATTEND MEETING RELATED TO THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE ASOFFERED BY THE NATIONAL PARKS SERVICE.OUR TRIBAL MEMBERS AND ALL OF THE TRIBAL, FEDERAL, AND STATE AGENCY STAFF THAT WE INTERACT WITH BENEFIT FROM OURTRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE WORK. OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES INCLUDE MAKING SURE WE INCREASE THERELATIONSHIPS WE HAVE WITH OTHER ENTITIES, AND THE PUBLIC THROUGH TRAININGS, PRESENTATIONS, AND OUTREACH. OURMEASURES TO IDENTIFY BENCHMARKS ARE QUANTITIATIVE IN THE NUMBER OF EVENTS AND PEOPLE WHO PARTICIPATE IN THESEACTIVITIES BUT ALSO QUALTITATIVE IN THE FEEDBACK WE GET FROM PARTICIPANTS THAT TELL US HOW MUCH OUR OUTREACH ISAPPRECIATED.
